VVVVVV is about going up and down. You go up to avoid some obstacles and go down to land safely between spikes. I have to mention that controls are very simple - left, right, swap gravity. There is open map that allows you to complete levels in custom order. Great retro style soundtrack included. I should mention that in this game you have to understand the gravity of the situation.

												+ Incredible 8-bit soundtrack; it really is some of the better gaming music I've had the pleasure of enjoying+ Level designs and platforming puzzles are challenging, but not to the point of relentless frustration+ Every screen of playable area has a name (visible at the bottom of the screen), and they're mostly strange and cheeky enough to keep the gameplay lighthearted+ Reversing gravity on a whim is a novel approach to the patforming genre, and works seemelessly+ Frequent checkpoints do much to divorce frustration from the experience+ There is a satisfying lack of loading and continue screens; lives are basically infinite, so that risk-taking is less detrimental+ Various platforming staples (e.g., moving platforms, fast-travelling obstructions, sprites, etc.) make a presence in differing zones of the map- Time required to complete the story will likely clock in around 3 hours, give or take, and I see little replay value beyond a push to collect trinkets and achievementsLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												VVVVVV is a platformer. Are you surprised yet? You shouldn't. On with the review:This game has caught my attention when it appeared on the Nintendo E-Shop on 2012. Being the person I was, I downloaded the $5 game (on the 3DS that eventually got stolen in 2014). It was worth every buck. The plot is very simple and quite complex when digging for a backstory.Let's focus on the basic right now: You are Captain Viridian. Your crew has been seperated in a strange, and facinating universe. And it is your job as captain to save them from the unknown dangers of this unknown world. With the power to flip upside-down, you can explore places where you thought never was possible. That's all you have for a power really: no attack, no special combat mechanics, just flipping. However it's all you need besides skill in this game: as everything can be avoided and can be done without dying a single time (no joke, everything is. I dare you to get the "Master of the Universe" achivement.). Along the way, you may find "Shiny Trinkets". These come to a good use after beating the game..after collecting all 20 (forget what I said earlier about "not dying". One of them requires you to activate a specific checkpoint and suicide.). I'm not going to list them or spoil anything since the steam community already did (plus this is a review, not a strategy guide).There are 4-5 (depends if you count the Lab areas as one area or two different sections) major areas in the game (not counting the transmission levels or the final level) all that can be accessed from the very large overworld in any order you like (minus the Transmission and Final levels). This brings for a total of 7-8 Levels in the entire game. Again, you have 20 Trinkets hidden in this entire world to search for along the way.The music & presentation is just excellent with everything being retro, and it gives that Atari vibe really well. Still, the music is just awesome! Souleye did a great job with creating the wonderful soundtrack for this game, as well as the 3 songs added in one of the updates. In fact many people have claimed the soundtrack to be the best part of the game. (Hint hint, tag on the game)It's mechanics are quite simple to grasp, such as moving platforms, vasnishing platforms, enemies, you know: the usual. The new comes in with the Warps. There are two types. One where you enter the side of a room, you are teleported to the exact other side. The other is a portal. Quite expected: you would be taken to a particular place in the world. You'll never know where it goes unless you used the portal once or twice.Must I say the Level Design is very fair, balanced at times, and very devious. How is all of this possible? Simple: Each area has their own "special" quality, including the transmission levels. The Lab, for example, focuses on Gravity Lines and you have to use these to do some flips you thought you wouldn't be able to do. The devious part comes in with some of the enemy placement, spike placement, and even the name of the room. Yes, every single room in the entire game has a name: which for me makes it more enjoyable. "What tricks you have up your sleeve this time?" However due to the game allowing you to access it's various levels at your leasure, it's hard to tell an accurate difficulty curve, especially with the varying mechanics thrown around. The transmission levels make up for the difficulty with one being an escort mission and the other throwing you into a survival challenge. The final level doesn't feel too hard, as you are having to apply what you learned, along with some mind-bending chaos. There is a good amount of extra content too: such as Time Trial mode (each time trial is unlocked after beating the actual level in-game), Flip Mode (after beating the game for the first time), player made levels that come with the game, and other levels that people in the community made..which brings me to the next topic: the Level Designer.You can create your dream levels of pure difficulty or possibly test out a few new things that can or cannot break the game. Again, you are the creator and stuff. Scripting is quite difficult to learn, but it's easy to input them once learned. And you have access to almost everything in the game. Checkpoints, various crew members, etc. So the levels are basically micro versions of the game, but customized to the max.In the end, VVVVVV is a classic game in my steam library that I was glad to experience once again. Would I advise someone like Jirard (aka "The Completionist") to play this game? If you are tough as nails and can handle the challenge of 100% Super Meat Boy (at the very least), this probably be another game down the cake walk. However this can be quite difficult for new players. If you are going to go as far as 100% the game, prepare to die..a lot. You will suffer if you attempt that no-death run. I've only done it ONCE. Just ONCE on my 3DS. Just don't go that far as I did. If your curious, I still love the game even after all of that torture I went through. I know, I am very insanely crazy. And I will likely be even more crazy over the next coming years.

number of helpful: 135 of 201 people (67%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Time for a controversial review. I’ve played this game on and off for the past 5 years, and I’ve gradually come to realize it's not that great. I’ll try to explain why.To get one thing out of the way, the music is fantastic. The chiptune album “PPPPPP” is a true modern classic, catchy and energetic and well-produced. The game sells for $5, but I’d be willing to pay $20 for the soundtrack alone. It’s that good. Even after hearing these tunes for 5 years, most of them still haven’t gotten old to me. But chances are you’ve already heard the music and know this for yourself.To get another thing out of the way, I think the visuals are awesome. The minimalistic art throws back to a time older than the NES, and the ever-changing neon colors are strange and mysterious in their simplicity, and demand to be explored. In a way, the game itself is a fitting music video to one of the greatest chiptune albums there is.So, what do I dislike about this game? Well, where do I start…?The game is built around a novel idea – flipping the gravity of your character instead of jumping – and then spends an hour or two trying to pretend this mechanic has no crippling limitations before just giving up.  And I’m not exaggerating here: the entire game can be consistently beaten in about 30 minutes. The first time I played it, it took me about 50. Finding all the hidden trinkets can take about an hour more, depending on how many tries it takes you on the “Prize for the Reckless” and “Veni, Vidi, Vici” challenges.Most games which are built around a central gimmick will try to expand it with additional game mechanics. VVVVVV comes up with about four new mechanics to complement its gravity-flipping gimmick: conveyer belts, automatic-flip lasers, auto-scrolling rooms, and rooms that wrap around the edges. It then uses each of these mechanics in a tiny dungeon area and almost nowhere else. Two of the game’s areas use a somewhat irritating mechanic where you have to lead a friend around, with the level design poking fun at the fact that your friend has no common sense and you have to do everything for them. As far as new ideas are concerned, that’s pretty much it.The central hub area, which comprises the majority of the map, is mostly just empty space: no enemies, no platforming puzzles, nothing but a few spikes here and there and a few of the collectable trinkets hidden away in corners. Even the interesting mazes are scarce. The hopelessly catchy track “Passion for Exploring” plays in the central hub, but in this case, “exploration” means just repeatedly falling through dozens of empty screens and searching for the next dungeon entrance. The overworld is also littered with dozens of checkpoints and teleporters which you will never use because there’s just nothing out there. They could have removed it entirely, replacing the hub with a series of teleporters to the dungeons, and the game hardly would have lost anything.The game is touted as a “super hard” and “tough as nails” platformer. If that’s the case, it’s the easiest “super hard” platformer I’ve ever played. Some parts are hard, but there’s no steady sense of progression; the difficulty is mostly just limited to a few problem rooms which may take hundreds of deaths each, but otherwise the whole game is smooth sailing. If you want real difficulty, you can try no-death mode or the time trials, but it just amounts to repeatedly playing the same ridiculously short game until you get it perfect. In this case, the difficulty is mostly just self-imposed rather than the work of a level designer. Personally, I’ve spent the most amount of time on the Super Gravitron, a fearsomely difficult mini-game that was probably the spiritual precursor to Super  Hexagon.The game’s story might as well not be there. I can summarize the story as follows: “You are some kind of captain of some kind of crew piloting some kind of ship, which crash-lands on some kind of planet due to some kind of disturbance. In order to escape, you need to deactivate some kind of device located in some kind of alternate dimension.” I’m not exaggerating. Nothing is explained. This story could have been mysterious and compelling, but instead it chooses to go the “self-referential humor” route by having the characters poke fun at checkpoints and the level design, while they’re not busy talking about nothing.And for those who say “Why would you play this game for the story?” I propose that you consider this: the game’s story could have been better if you removed all of the dialogue. The story is told perfectly through the visuals. The explosions, lost crew members, and alternate dimensions are all self-explanatory, and it would have left all the details up to the imagination. Captain Viridian would have made a great silent protagonist that you could have projected your own motivation into. Instead, the characters are all given completely needless speaking lines which don’t convey anything, and I’m just left wondering why anyone bothered to write dialogue.TL,DR: Aside from the superb music and the visuals, VVVVVV feels like a game that was hastily thrown together. The difficulty is schizophrenic, rather than a fine-tuned progression curve. The overworld map is mostly empty space, as though the level designer had tried filling it with enemies and mazes but finally said “screw it, nothing works” and deleted everything. The story had no effort behind it. Interesting game mechanics are few and far between, and are only used for a few rooms each. The bonus game modes are needless masochism that are far too great of a difficulty jump from the main game. Overall, it feels more like an hour-long proof of concept than a full-fledged game exploring the possibilities and implications of its main gravity-flipping gimmick.Yes, it was influential. Yes, it rode the very first wave of indie games back when Steam was gaining steam. Yes, the music is crazy good. All things considered, I respect this game. But after five years of playing and reflecting on it, I can’t help but see it as a short, pointless waste of time with no interesting gameplay statements to make (even for its time) and no heart put into it. It’s style-over-substance. But hey, it’s got a great style, so I can’t quite fault it for that. I know a lot of people love this game. I loved it for a while, but now that I've noticed its flaws I can't shake the sour taste this game leaves me with.I know that few will agree with my sentiment, but hopefully I’ve explained my thoughts adequately.And finally, all achievement hunters but the most dedicated should stay far, far away. This is one brutal 100%.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												VVVVVV is perhaps the most fun I've ever had being tortured with a game this side of Super Meat Boy.It's a sublime DOS inspired platformer where inverting the gravity has replaced your jump button, requiring you to completely rethink how you approach a level. Platforms are setup in a way that require incredibly precise, conscious flips and movement to surpass, at times feeling almost impossibly difficult. But VVVVVV is never unfair, offering you an abundance of checkpoints and excessively precise controls that caused me to surprise myself with what I was capable of. The nonlinear design also allows you to opt out of some of the most challenging rooms, or revisit them later when you feel better in tune with the game. Completing the game will test your mettle regardless, but the sense of accomplishment and the ever present feeling that you can possibly surpass any challenge given just one more time makes it impossible to give up and extremely rewarding when you do eventually succeed (though all the same, "Doing it the hard way" will forever haunt my nightmares).VVVVVV's vision is so strong and consistent, that even though the experience lasts only a few hours it was so incredibly fun and well put together that I never noticed the short length as I was simply having too good a time getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me again and again. That's probably a peculiar way to recommend a game, but VVVVVV is something of a peculiar game, coming out of essentially nowhere, putting blisters on my fingers, and making me curse and rejoice over and over while what can only be described as the best music to ever enter your ear holes played in the background.It's good, so just play it already won't you?!You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												VVVVVV is an amazing journey through space and a mystical dimension trying to desperately save your friends and get back home safely. The gameplay is excellent and the retro graphics really make an impact even in their simplicity. This is by no means a long game. In fact I finished it in less than two hours in my first serious try. The thing is, you shouldn’t really expect anything else from the game. It’s a super fun bite-sized goodie with a lot to offer if you just give it a chance. The game is pretty simple and straight forward. There aren’t many mechanics but mastering the few there are is a challenge in itself. The soundtrack by Magnus (SoulEye) Pålsson is magnificent. It keeps you pumped up for the action and keeps the flow of the game up even if you happen to die 50 times in a single room. Overall, if you like retro platformers, this is a must buy. It’s not quite a masterpiece contender since the length barely gets you started with the game and the gameplay is super simplistic. Still, you’ll definitely get your money’s worth out of VVVVVV.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												One of the most brilliant games I've ever played. Don't let the retro style fool you, the game is as far from taking the easy route design-wise as possible. The levels are well designed and offer optional challenges for even the most hardcore completionists/masochists. The flip-flop control scheme works perfectly, and the levels are designed around it, not thrown together to accomodate it.The atmosphere is fantastic, the Commodore-ish visuals and sound actually manage to create a pretty spooky world, although I'd say the challenging difficulty has something to do with that too.The only thing I wish this game had is Steam achievements, as it definitely is a great game to complete 100%.Right now it's on sale for 30 cents, so I see absolutely no reason not to buy this game instead of a few Steam trading cards. And even at the $3 full price it's worth every penny.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Before I played this game, I thought that it was going to be a very simple game with a few levels. Oh how I was wrong. VVVVVV has a whole story where you, as the captain of  a spaceship, must find and save all your missing crew members. Each step of the way there is a creative level, each one being very challenging. Futhermore, there are a total of 20 'trinkets' which you can (try) to collect, some of which took me 100s of tries before I finally got them.Each level is named in a lightheartedly funny way and the soundtrack really helps to quash any fustration the immense difficulty of the game brings. Even after you finish the rather short main game, there is so much more to do with the inclusion of time trials and a 'flipped mode'.Overall, this game is a short yet very sweet retro adventure that is both difficult to play and rewarding to complete.10/10

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												This is the best platformer released in the last decade. There's absolutely no fat. Mechanics are introduced, tested, refined, developed, plumbed, and discarded within 10 minutes, and it feels totally organic. The open world feels even better than Super Metroid, and the individual world-segments are beautifully self-contained. Every single platforming puzzle works. It doesn't overstay its welcome; it has about 3-4 hours worth of content, and that's exactly how long it'll take you. Every screen makes your grin wider as you realize that, yes, they did just pull that trick out of the bag. There's something to be said for perfectly executed modesty. What's wonderful is that despite the handful of mechanics, they all descend from one base mechanic--you can flip from ceiling to floor or vice versa but can't change directions during a flip. That's it.The crown jewel is an optional sequence called "Veni, Vidi, Vici" which is the one of the most challenging sequences I've played in a game in years and so so satisfying when you beat it. What's most poignant about the VVV sequence (and thus VVVVVV as a whole) is that the theme of being able to do these amazing space flips but not even make a little hop causes both thematic frustration--I can see that damn shiny trinket, why the hell can't I climb over this block and get there--and puzzle-related frustration. Wonderful.

content:

												Amazing 8-bit platformer, I've spent countless hours playing it back in old days, then I decided to buy it on steam (you know that happens >____> ) to support the dev. number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game, VVVVVV, it calls itself. A mess of letters that blend together into a mess of jagged lines, as if to trace one's path through life in a retrospective essay of Adobe Flash and Steam winter sales. It infuriates me. But not for the reasons one might expect, no, not the usual cries of difficulty and despair.I double-click the name in my Steam library and prepare for the worst. Forty nine cents, I say. This game cost me less than a round of slightly clogged arteries from the local fast food joint and was paid for entirely by selling virtual headwear and trading cards to those less fortunate than myself. Surely I will be able to find some modicum of enjoyment of this mess of Flash. Flash? Perhaps not! The forums of the Internet tell me that at one point it was remade in a proper programming language. As such, the game can suffer random slowdowns in fullscreen and neither the Steam overlay nor capture software such as Fraps will recognize the game. I found myself unable to take and upload screenshots of my trials in this pixelated, single-colored world, for all to see but none to comment on. A Google search leads to a Steam forum post regarding then-'soon' updates for overlays, achievements and the Cloud. The famous Cloud. This post dates from over two years ago. The Cloud has since been implemented to questionable effect, but now there are a host of colorful trinket achievements to chase. Did you already play the game to completion before their appearance? You're out of luck, buddy, do it again, they say. Alt-tabbing the game will lock your cursor in the corner of your screen and sometimes just crash. This game was not built on Source, they tell me. They're lying to me.The game itself controls acceptably. Sometimes I find myself sliding off platforms and into hazards and sometimes getting stuck inside either. Platformers should not have slippery controls like this, but the air control is precise and exact. Why is there such a difference? Is there an underlying message to be found here, perhaps describing the trials of Man trapped in his earthly plane? I would hope not, as this game predates the trend of waves upon waves of lazy, 'deep' indie ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t by several years. To the untrained eye it appears to fit quite well, though, with the simplistic graphics and chiptune soundtrack.This. This is where this executable of poor optimization and developer laziness gets to me. The game's art style is obviously meant to harken back to an era of dial-up and diskettes, in truth even earlier than both. Simple graphics and single color palettes attempt to imitate the limitations of old, yet miss the mark entirely. The developers want you to think you're playing a Commodore 64 game, down to including an imitation tape deck load screen upon startup, and yet they so clearly miss the appeal of the C64. Why go for plain, blocky graphics when it was capable of so much more? Why use a soundtrack consisting entirely of generic chiptunes churned out in Fruityloops in an afternoon when the Commodore was famous for its SID chip, used even today for its unique sound and characteristics? This was perhaps the biggest indicator of Vee Six's origins.Vee Six? Yes, that will do. I feel it fits this game nicely. You wanted the big American V8 with more displacement than the total Coke bottles in a shopping cart at Wal-Mart, but instead went for the more frugal six-cylinder for better gas mileage. Perhaps it shows up under a different name, like Grand Sport or Touring, but the illusion disappears as soon as the hood is opened and the guts of the machine become visible. Likewise, you wanted a game that harkens back to the days of incredible difficulty, but without actually playing a game from that era, so you bought Vee Six.It was quite ahead of its time, really, this poor little game. Perhaps it actually started the trend of retro-throwback games that only appear as such to the untrained, Mountain Dew chugging eye, taking a small break from his endless stacks of semi-futuristic first person shooters starring Sgt. Master Sgt. Technician of Operations Captain Slabmeat and his sidekicks, Alpha Team Bravo Charlie Omega. I have doubts about his ability to find such a game, though. This seems like one meant for that other audience, the one that cuddles into their woolen hat at the corner coffee house while typing on their ridiculously overpriced, shining white laptop and adjusting their lensless, thick-framed glasses. A game for those who want to go back... but not really, because they never experienced what they would be going back to in the first place. An imitation that falls apart like that disgusting hipster's Volkswagen as it gets driven around a small upstate city in New York looking for guys in skinny jeans and no shoes while struggling from no oil changes to no oil changes.So. An interesting word, 'so.' Both a statement and a question. So what? So this is a review, after all. Reviews have to have one final word, else the whole page might as well be used as a paper airplane to send your thoughts and dreams. In these modern times of instant messaging and ironic tendencies, no one has time to read more than exactly one hundred forty-four characters without requesting a short-form so their attention deficit disorder-afflicted minds can process that one tidbit of information before riding the rollercoaster of latest trends down the next incline while that child in the back row vomits all over himself and the poor sod sitting beside. Do I recommend this game? The question weighed heavily on my mind for days on end, pervading every waking moment with its incessant inquisition.Yes. I suppose I can recommend this game, if you enjoy throwing money at walls to throw a small, single-color, virtual person at a wall over and over. I move my mouse and hesitantly click the checkmark instead of the thumbs-down icon. Nobody reads negative reviews, after all, and unfortunately there is no option for 'indifference' or perhaps 'Yes, but only if on sale first.' I paid forty nine American pennies for a sadomasochism simulator in the guise of a 'retro' platformer game.I should have found two more quarters in my couch and bought a burger.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
-Quick Review-I'm still not really sure why it's called VVVVVV, I remember playing the game expecting the game to be chaotic, but it actually was a fairly entertaining game and interesting game. The game is a 2D exploration/adventure game that feels like something I would play on a classic GameBoy. -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You are the captain of a ship and you have lost your crew mates! you need to go save them and get collect various artifacts of the strange world you're now stranded on. This game will give you various fun, enjoyable puzzles.At the time that I'm writing this review (08/20/14) I haven't completed the story, I stopped half way through, and then achievements were added so now I've boosted up when I want to complete and play this game. :DGame Play: I cannot say enough about simple controls. I love simple controls, jump, right, left, up, down. That's all you need.As I said earlier, the game plays like something you might play on a Classic GameBoy cartridge, I've never had a problem playing games which low graphics, it actually makes the game more fun and easier to play on mobile or smaller devices like laptops.The puzzles can sometimes be challenging but the game itself is very simple in nature and quite forgiving. As you progress or try to get special extra's the game challenges you more. I installed this game without expecting anything at all, and I was pleasantly surprised to find myself enjoying the game. (I've played 32 minutes worth of content before achievements were added) Achievements: At this time I haven't earned any of these achievements, but I had a glance and most of the achievements seem pretty straight forward. Beat the game, beat the game without dying X amount of times, do this interesting thing for X amount of time, Beat the game in X amount of time.The achievements look a bit last-luster and uninteresting but there really isn't much they can do with the game, and ultimately it's impressive that there are achievements at all for a 2D game with graphics this low.Price: VVVVVV is currently $4.99 That's a bit high of a price for a game if you don't plan to play it, I got the game for $1 on a 90% off sale in the steam 2013 Summer Sale. There is also a demo version of the game, which I would recommend trying out.Whenever there's a Demo you should try out the demo just to see if you actually like the content inside the game. It's good to read reviews for how a game plays, but testing out the graphics and game play for yourself is second too none. Conclusion: Most people are put off by the idea of playing a 2D game, especially one with very low graphics that looks like it was made for a very old game system, but I've always enjoyed games, both high quality, low quality, and in-between.I recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a short little game to play through that won't take up much memory, and has a few hours to burn. I also recommend it to anyone who already knows they don't mind low quality graphics in their video games.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2013
												A challenging and stylish puzzle platformer.V's gameplay and design elevate it beyond another puzzle platformer. The game revolves around an intersting mechanic where the player can reverse the gravity of their character (Captain Viridian), causing him to flip between the floor and ceiling. Extremely clever level design makes using this mechanic fun, challenging, and rewarding. The minimalist style, both in art and narrative, manages to display a lot of character. Some of the dialogue suggests a bit of narrative, not enough to floor anyone, but it adds to making the game feel personal and whole. The art style also showcases the level design nicely, which is the highlight of the game. The soundtrack is icing on the cake.On top of the main mission of fighting your crew, you can also unlock extra bits of soundtrack by collecting "shiny trinkets," which adds extra challenge and length to the game.Finishing a level in V is extremely satisfying; there is a definite, and fair challenge present. Brilliant level design, gameplay, and aesthetics make  V an excellent game.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Even though I loved Super Hexagon so much, I was wary of VVVVVV a little bit, just because of the reputation of it being kind of difficult. I'm not very good at platformers, and I often get annoyed with them. But, even though I died over 1600 times finishing this game, each death only filled me with hope and determination. Every time I pressed the wrong button and ran into spikes, or didn't press any button and ran into spikes, or fell onto spikes, or jumped into spikes for no reason, or any of the other 1600 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed things I did, I just felt more resolve to finish this game. Even the 400 deaths on Veni Vidi Vici just made made me want to get it even more after each try.The graphics are gorgeous, the music absolutely perfect, and even though it's a small thing, the room names were a standout. Sometimes encouraging, sometimes ironic, sometimes scathing, it was like having a biting narrator quip over your shoulder while pretending they weren't really interested in what you're doing. This is a triumph for Terry Cavanagh. I'm proud of myself for finishing this game. I'll be even prouder when I 100% it (hah!).

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												If you had told me before VVVVVV that a difficult platformer with a simple concept that is based around precision-timing jumps would not only not give me a burning desire to throw the controller at the screen in frustration, but that I would actually have a hard time letting go of said controller for almost the whole duration of the game, you probably would've gotten a face full of sarcastic laughter (which sounds eerily like the Super Meat Boy tune). Or, more likely, I would've ignored your suggestion until I got the game half-free as part of a Humble Bundle (sorry, brother, your suggestions are the best!) and had no excuse not to play this highly-praised game. I enjoy quality platforming as much as most gamers and don't mind the difficulty that typically comes with such games, especially when they are indie-made. But I need to be in a very specific mindset if I am to endure countless re-attempts at the slightest mistake and I run out of that energy eventually regardless of how far I got in the game. VVVVVV rectifies the image of indie platformers you have in your head with a surprising breath of clarity - even the confusing name makes perfect sense after staring at those same spikes room after room. Instead of jumping, you switch gravity back and forth so that you're either standing on ground or on the ceiling - and that's all there is to it. No upgrades, no weapons, everything you come across is doable from the get-go. The world is open, reminiscent of Metroidvania games, but even with a minimal plot and the ability to choose your own path, playng is straight-forward and you never feel lost.What could've been only a gimmick or proof-of-concept-gameplay comes together as a tight, addictive package, thanks to the gratituous use of checkpoints. There is typically at least one in each room and as you die you reappear next to it without further hassle, so once you figure out how to gravity-change yourself out of the next pickle or ace the pixel-tight patterns of moving obstacles, you're safe again.  Dying constantly is not only allowed, it's celebrated, with the total number of deaths in your current playthrough proudly displayed in the menu. There are Steam achievements for finishing the game with a small number of deaths, but you don't have to care about that unless you really want to. You can collect trinkets in the game, which unlocks some extras, and there are a few which can test your patience, but thanks to the checkpoints, you don't have to memorize minutes of tough manouvers; it's all finely chopped down.Of course, the platforming in this game is still challenging - if you didn't enjoy the joys of precision jumping in a game like the original Super Mario Brothers, you probably won't enjoy this. But the game isn't needlessly or falsely difficult. VVVVVV presents itself as exactly as it is, trial-and-error gameplay in the word's most positive sense. You can focus on the platforming puzzles without being punished for dying while trying to get a "feel" of each room's pattern. Each new checkpoint reached feels like a little win and you get through even the more difficult parts with the knowledge that the gameplay is logical and rewards your patient learning, not luck.Of course, the game also has a great soundtrack and little details like the amusing dialogue and room names. My biggest grief is with the Steam Achievements; they should be more varied. Finishing with less and less deaths makes sense as a challenge, as do the flip mode and no-death mode achievements, but the many Super Gravitron and perfect Time Trial achievements seem pointless and don't motivate to play more.

												Basic platformer indies have invaded gaming like a virus constantly multiplying which makes it hard to find a worthwhile one. VVVVVV is deserving of your time. Cheery chip tunes and cute smiling characters set the upbeat tone. As long as you can appreciate the minimalistic art design enough to stomach the potentially seizure inducing flares of bright colors on-screen, there is interesting platforming to be explored here. Platforming difficulty ranges from gleefully intriguing to seemingly impossible, though it should be mentioned the hardest sections are optional. Product received for free
												Are you a fellow Metroid fan suffering the drought of Nintendo's midlife crisis? Well. then buy this game immediately. The sense of exploration gives off the vibes of the first four Metroid games, while still feeling fresh and creative. The gravity reverse mechanic may sound like a lazy gimmick, but actually is put to great use throughout the game. It's a bit challenging, but it almost never feels unforgiving or unfair. It's also really cheap. It's only a fraction of the price of buying your average retail game, so it's worth every penny. Well, granted, the game was gifted to me, but that's besides the point. Buy it.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												A charming game done in the style of retro video games. It revolves around one simple mechanic: manipulating gravity to avoid various obstacles.PROS:-very unique gameplay that's very easy to get into-soundtrack will give you an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as your ears are filled with the sounds of those retro beats-if you're into retro gaming the art style will satisfy your needs-an excellent time killer-lots of secrets to find-it comes bundled with a lot of community levels if you're finished the main storyCONS:-not a lot of replayability in the main story unless you're aiming for a few achievements-some areas have a difficulty spike without any warning-the game is rather shortOverall the game itself is really enjoyable. I highly recommend this to anybody who just wants a small game to play in their spare time and is looking for a good challenge.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2011
												Ah, VVVVVV. I got this as part of a pack of games during the 2010 steam holiday sale. I don't even know what else was in the package. Five dollars for this game, by itself, is a fricken bargain. The graphics are aggressively retro, bringing you back to your DOS days of command prompts and computers with no harddrive(er, if you're old, like me). The soundtrack is sublime. The controls are deliberately floaty and imprecise; Like with Super Meat boy, this is a game where you need to learn restraint in order to achieve precision, a game where you're constantly sliding after landing and flying further than you intended. Every action has inertial consequences. But unlike super meat boy, it's less reactive, its inertial force harder to fight, and thus more consistent and predictable yet no less difficult. Where the slightest backtap could mean spikey death in SMB, which makes Meatboy feel weightless and heavy at the same time, VVVVVV feels consistently heavy but low-gravity, and therein lies its brilliance.Fantastic. Just really good.PS: I played this to completion before they added achievements; I don't know how complete I'd have gotten it but I do know I finished the game with all the shiny trinkets(though, it must be said, dying hundreds of times along the way).

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												Indeed not a long game but it's not a short game either, a lot can be taken from the experience and alot can be explored in the game by collecting collectables, etc... Storywise it's straightforward, save your friends by going through puzzles and exploring, a normal story line which can lead to a few twists while saving a few of them. The soundtrack is something I found dear about this game, going through level by level, dying over and over with the soundtrack keeping me in high spirits and makes me want to keep playing, the whole puzzle and "press space to invert gravity" is a nice touch and can lead to some challenging puzzles which can take effort to get through but is worth to say the least but there is one part that stands out the most challenging and that is "Veni Vidi Vici" which in order to get a collectable you have to go though this insanely difficult challenge which I could not do so I had to leave it, the ending is something to look forward to with the game ending with the last legit level called "VVVVVV" which gave me the chills, I do recommend the game to anyonle who enjoys puzzle games with a challenging aspects to them, in my belief I'd like to say this game is a masterpeice and just by looking at the title you'd thing some kid just held down the V key with Caps Lock on but really it can have more meanings than that like the 5 characters names all starting with V, etc... but back to the point, this game is an interesting take on puzzle/indie games and would hope more games like these would rise.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												VVVVVV. Ah yes. This is a game that is beautiful because of it's simplicity. The mechanics are simple, the story is simple, the art is simple. VVVVVV is a masterwork of platforming. It can be infintely frustrating, especially for a ompletionist who wants to find all 20 of the shiny trinkets, but finally getting through the tower or executing a correct jump around a slingshot bend after 20+ deaths comes with an incredible sense of accomplishment. My friend and I recorded a let's play of VVVVVV for our youtube channel, and it was both fun and arduous. I died over 1500 times in my first run of the game, and we ran a death counter to prove it. But I had fun. And after 2.5 hours of play, I walked away from the computer able to say that I beat "that infernal platformer". With that said, it is not the most murdurous of the platformers, and it can help ease people into themore homicidal games (Super Meat Boy). I highly recommend it. The title is also fun.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												VVVVVV is a fantastic puzzle/adventure game with a unique style of gameplay and brilliantly designed levels for newbies and experts alike. Your ship has crashed and you are now in an alternate world! The only problem now is that you have lost all of your shipmates. Embark on a gravity changing journey as you move from the floor, to the ceiling and back, and find your friends. This game is one of a kind and should only take you a few hours to complete. VVVVVV is definitely worth the time; it includes dungeon-esque levels with many hidden secrets and a large world full of puzzles that you use gravity to solve. If you are looking for a unique and overlooked gem, consider buying this game today.

												A perfect game, on all compartments.Want to play for the story? Then hop on a journey to rescue your crew-mates who got lost in space, the game is extremely fun and with a "normal" difficulty degree if you don't go for trophies.Want more challenge? Then get to play one of the most balanced, fair, and difficult arcade platformers ever made (yes there are speedrunners too).Everything I wrote above seasoned with an intense mixture of 8-bit music and graphics that are just perfect, nothing more to add.If you're unsure you may like the game or not (if you don't then probably you don't understand what's good and bad and you don't deserve this game) you can try the first two levels on kongregate, somewhere.Anyway I recommend this game to everyone, even just to understand when you can really say that a game is GOOD and not just fancy or cool like most games nowadays.

content:

Product received for free
												I hate indie, but Very Fun Game! The retro-esque gravity defying platformer VVVVVV takes one back to the days of better gaming -- where skill actually matters because the reward is worth it. You'll find the game-play difficult but not overly so and the payoff of finding new areas or making an "impossible" maneuver worthwhile. The music gives me goosebumps and fits in quite well with the game -- that of exploring space in an strange and unknown dimension to find your crew-mates. Precision platforming -- retro style -- at its best! 10/10.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												VVVVVV takes a retro approach with its aesthetics. And while this no-nonsense style can be appealing in its own way, what really hooks you when you play this game is its consistently creative level design and its devious challenge. It's fun to explore VVVVVV's open world and tackle its levels in any order. Be prepared to die plenty of times, but generous checkpoints and that distinct sense of accomplishment after clearing difficult sections will keep you satsified and pushing onwards.

												This game, guys. This game is awesome.Okay, so to give an introduction, VVVVVV is a super difficult 2D platformer, where you have to get through a bunch of challenging levels to rescue crewmates of your crashed spaceship. You can also collect Shiny Trinkets, which if you get all 20 of, you get access to the Secret Lab and the Super Gravitron.It's very open ended, because after the first level, you can do the rest of the game in any order you like. And while this no-nonsense style can be appealing in its own way, what really hooks you when you play this game is its consistently creative level design and its devious challenge. It's fun to explore VVVVVV's open world and tackle its levels in any order. Be prepared to die plenty of times, but generous checkpoints and that distinct sense of accomplishment after clearing difficult sections will keep you satsified and pushing onwards.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												VVVVVV takes a simple mechanic (flipping gravity) and explores it to its fullest potential. Between the wonderful music, creative levels, and charming retro art style (more in homage to the C64 than the NES) your first playthrough will be a joy from beginning to end. And if you put down the game there, the experience would be worthwhile.But the game's real challenge comes from trying to beat the game with the fewest number of deaths. On a casual run, deaths have no real impact, aside from taking you back to your last checkpoint, of which there are plenty. But once you know the layout of the game, the focus changes from exploration to mastery. Personally, I am not one to care about time trials or speedrunning, or any arbitrary reason to replay the same game over and over again, but VVVVVV is a rare exception to that; the gameplay and level design is just so tight, that each playthrough feels as fresh as the last. And the game length is just perfect for the occasional replay to try and improve your death count.I think this game has something to offer all fans of retro platformers, whether that's exploring the simple world and finding its secrets, trying to collect all of the optional (and often frustratingly hard) trinkets, or replaying the game to improve upon your best score.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												This is a ridiculously entertaining game once you get a hang of the chief mechanic: Instead of jumping, you reverse gravity. There are myriad applications of this practice, and while it may take some time to comprehend, you'll soon be pulling off anti-gravity parkour techniques and surviving. Not to mention that this game has an adorable cast of V's that are all willing to help you learn the secrets of Dimension VVVVVV...provided that you help them find each other first. There's puzzles that will test your wits, willpower, endurance, and creativity, and special collectibles that will dare you to take things one step further, with rewards waiting for you in return for that hard work.And if you get this game, don't skip out on the soundtrack. This game's music is delightfully catchy, and soon you'll flip every time you hear it.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is a hesitant recommendation. I liked the game a lot at first, but as I play more it feels like bundle fodder more than a solid game. It's short and focused on replaying for completion, but the game doesn't seem to change much in replaying. The only real reason to replay is to seek out all the achievements, but that will be an agonizing process of precision and deaths.I like how it focuses on one mechanic, flipping gravity, and plays with it in many good ways. However, that makes platforming a bit rough. Since "jumps" are based on left/right motion and timing of flips, I think the devs intentionally made left/right motion INCREDIBLY slipppery. See, you slide on every surface like you are a dog♥♥♥♥♥♥icicle, accelerating like a madman and never able to take a small step. Platforming becomes very unforgiving with smaller windows of mistakes. It IS satisfying when you complete some sections quickly, but most likely you will feel aggravated relief after you finally complete a painful section. The "Do as I say, Not as I do" section will show you how bad the sliding can be.I like the concept and style, but the execution makes it difficult to enjoy. However, it could be far worse. The short length and open paths means you can complete sections as you please (for the most part) and see the core of the game to completion with some patience. Eversion is even shorter but far more frustrating. And Yet It Moves takes the flipping idea, applies it to 4 directions, adds enemies and awkward physics, and kills you if you fall too far. AYIM is one of the games I hate the most.So, it's interesting, and done better than most. Still frustrating and handles awkwardly with the acceleration, but I hesitantly recommend if you are a platforming fan wanting something new to replay for time trials.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												From the outside, VVVVVV may just look like another retro-styled game that uses its retro factor to hide the fact that it's just another generic platformer. While the former may be true, this is definitely not your average platformer.The story of this game is simple: you're a captain of a spaceship and your crew has been scattered through another dimension due to some interference. You need to find them and stop the interference. The graphic style is heavily inspired by the Commodore 64's graphics, while the sountrack is more reminiscent of that of the NES. Both of these work great together, although they might not be amusing for someone is tired of retro styled indie games.VVVVVV is a metroidvania game: meaning that you can explore the dimension you're in looking for all sorts of things (crew members, trinkets, teleporters). What makes VVVVVV so special however is that you can't jump, but you can flip gravity so that you'll go up instead of down, and vice-versa. The concept is easy to learn (but incredibly hard to master), and leads to many creative levels. There will be some levels *cough*Doing Things The Hard Way*cough* that will usually frustrate the crap out of you, but at the same time you'll have a blast trying to figure out how to get through them (unless you are very easily frustrated, in which case, you should stay away from this game). On top of the main game, there are tons of other features that will keep you playing for hours, such as collecting all of the trinkets, time trials, various game modes (flip mode where the entire game is flipped upside down and no death mode where if you die once you have to restart the game), and even a level creator.VVVVVV will make you want to break your keyboard and you will love every minute of it. What makes this game even better is that it's often on sale for a low price (sometimes even $0.49!). This is a must have for those looking for a challenge.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												There are really two types of people in this world. Those who hate maddeningly frustrating twitch platformers like this one, and those who hate maddeningly frustrating twitch platformers like this one so much, they can't stop playing them. Spiritual elder sibling to "You Have To Win The Game," VVVVVV is to the Commodore 64 platformer of yore what its CGA cousin is to the DOS platformer of yore, and I cannot possibly recommend both games enough. To paraphrase the words that prefaced the Dungeons and Dragons rulebook so many years ago, those gamers who lack patience, those who don't care for Monty Mole's adventures through sprawling maps of tricky-to-navigate rooms, who feel no thrill upon waking up with Lester in the suspended cage in that famously Another World, who do not enjoy rubbing their palmheel raw on the molded plastic grip of an old one-button joystick with a nine-pin connector or trying hundreds of times to see what lies beyond that maddening gauntlet of hazards, even if it's just a blank room that hasn't been visited before, will not be likely to find VVVVVV to their tastes. But those whose curiosity knows no bounds and whose frustration tolerance rivals that of a Zen master will find this game the answer to their SID-soundtracked, load-star-comma-eight-comma-one prayers. The very simple graphics may put you off; don't let them. The six Vs of the title, the cast of the game, take a little getting-used-to, certainly, and I admit, I would have liked a slightly less stylized (if still period-appropriate) character model, but their simple Carcassone-like iconic cuteness grows on you, or at least a tolerance to it accumulates. The characters have two recognizable facial expressions, and their paddle-like, boxy heads are sized, I suspect, to accommodate those easily-recognizable expression changes. Without sharing spoilers, I should note that it becomes clear, later in the game, that their box-headed design was thematically intentional. If you don't like it, relax, and don't let that stop you from enjoying this amazing game.The backgrounds, with their stylized metal plating, single-color enemies, and two-plane-deep parallax scrolling gamefield, will be immediately recognizable to C64 fans, as will the bombastic, cheerful, strident soundtrack of in-game looped hits by Magnus Pålsson. While You Have To Win The Game offers only monophonic sound cues, in line with its pre-soundcard DOS-and-PC-speaker pedigree, VVVVVV feels much less stark and empty for its consistently cheerful, upbeat and hopeful tone, and the soundtrack plays a huge role in creating that atmosphere of "Let's play space explorers!" Saturday morning excitement. Again, like its cousin, the massive, sprawling map is liberally dotted with continue points, which make recovering from one of the game's many nigh-inevitable deaths less painful, as little ground must be regained afterward. Like its cousin, exploration is key, and will be rewarded -- the map view offers a tantalizing glimpse of area not yet traveled, and the desire to wipe away all the blank areas on it is strong. Like its cousin, the game's locales can be revisited after winning, explored anew, and there's a reward in store for completionists. Like its cousin, spikes are an ever-present and vexing environmental hazard. Like its cousin, there are a few graphic options that help to recreate a much more obviously retro gaming platform experience. (I love Analogue Mode, though I wish there was a way to reduce the frequency of vertical hold failures, or to turn off vertical hold failures completely.) So, you might be asking, how does VVVVVV differ from You Have To Win The Game? Quite significantly, despite their many similarities. First, the bombastic, upbeat optimism of the game is a stark contrast to YHTWTG's quiet and emptiness. There are no friends to be found in YHTWTG, while in VVVVVV, reuniting the titular Vs is, in fact, the primary goal of the game's main arc. (This is not a spoiler, for not; it's stated from the get-go.) Furthermore, while YHTWTG uses a fairly conventional run-and-jump platformer mechanic, there is no jump button in VVVVVV. Rather, the protagonist can reverse personal gravity, and elect to "fall up" rather than down, more or less at will.More or less, indeed. To flip gravity, one must first be standing on (at least momentarily) solid ground. A flip in progress must complete, and land successfully, before the player can flip again. Our brave Captain Viridian can steer mid-fall, but can't stop a fall. It is entirely possible to end up missing a safe landing point this way. Be grateful for those ubiquitous continue-points. You'll need them. At least, mercifully, one can't die from too long a fall.I've already mentioned the difference in mood, but beyond this, VVVVVV is communicative in a way YHTWTG isn't. The landscape is dotted with computer terminals hosting messages, and of course, there are five crew members to find and rescue. While YHTWTG offers no clues about its landscape, VVVVVV tells a coherent narrative, and while many questions are left unanswered, one leaves VVVVVV with a better sense of the events of the game in a narrative context than the state in which one leaves YHTWTG.VVVVVV offers some really spectacular accessibility features for gamers who would normally not be able to play this sort of game, too. One can slow down the game incrementally, turn off moving backgrounds and screen effects, or set the protagonist invincible. The granularity of slowdown control allows you to easily notch the game's reflexes-related difficulty back to a point where it's still challenging but playable, for those who can't react quickly enough at full game speed. This option, as opposed to simply implementing the invulnerability switch, shows a real solid understanding of not only what such a player might need, but how to provide it while preserving as much of the challenge of the game as said player wishes to face. It's rare that this much thought goes into accessibility accommodations, let alone in an indie game. Finally, VVVVVV offers tools to build one's own levels and scenarios, to bundle them up, and to share them with others. There are quite a few fan-made levels out there, and they're often quite impressive. Terry Cavanagh offers a free "Make and Play" edition of VVVVVV that creates and plays fan-made levels, allowing you to easily and legally share what you make with others. That feature alone extends VVVVVV far beyond the scope of YHTWTG, and makes it a real must-have at its $5 price point. (Frankly, it was more than worth its original $15 price point, too, but I'm glad the price dropped, and VVVVVV became a much more comfortable impulse buy for the still-unconvinced gamer.)VVVVVV will frustrate you. It will vex you. It will make you scream in frustration and insist it's 'impossible' at least once or twice, but then you'll sail past a difficult level and the palpable joy of your triumph will eclipse the frustration. (Veni Vidi Vici, anyone...?) If your frustration tolerance is limited, this is probably not the game for you. If you can't get beyond the lo-fi visual style, if "chiptunes" annoy you, if dying over and over again bothers you, and especially if you're not not a twitch-reflexes run-and-jumper (run-and-flipper?), then this is probably not your game.You're probably either put off or curious now. I hope you're curious. VVVVVV rewards curiosity, as long as it's tempered with a healthy dose of patience. Jump in, flip gravity, and rock out the soundtrack. This is a fun, sunny, bombastic return to Saturday mornings on the Commodore 64, in all the very best of ways.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												To hear the full review, listen to the episode on Game Hoard Podcast[soundcloud.com]VVVVVV is a great little platformer built around a single unique mechanic: instead of jumping, you have the ability to switch gravity up and down. This mechanic leads to some of the most inventive and challenging platforming gameplay I've ever encountered. Every single room becomes a platforming puzzle as you try to figure out how to use gravity to move through hostile environments without dying, which you will do often. Luckily, the game wastes no time respawning you at the nearest checkpoint, which are liberally sprinkled throughout the environment. VVVVVV also thankfully leaves lives and game overs out of the equation. The result is a game with a high challenge but that never feels punishing or impossible and moves forward at lightning speed.Also welcome is the open world game design that makes VVVVVV feel Metroidvania-esque. Different areas of the map have different sorts of obstacles and challenges, allowing you to explore and progress at your own pace.Another interesting aspect is the game's story, which does not feature a villain or enemies of any kind. The story feels like a small side quest happening in a larger world, which is a refreshing change from a typical platformer where you need to save the world/princess.It also has one of the best chiptune tracks that you will ever hear and features simple but effective graphics inspired by C64 games.Overall, VVVVVV is an immensely satisfying experience for anyone up to the challenge and I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 25
												In case you somehow haven't heard of this game by 2017, it's great. The game is very simple, with the only mechanics on your character being moving left and right, as well as reversing gravity. Rather than tacking on endless amounts of abilities, which can be fun, this game instead introduces a level-specfic gimmick, gets your comfortable with it, and demands perfection. This game can be tough, REALLY tough. But even when it's tough it so ingenius that you want to pull on. There are frequent checkpoints too in case you screw up often, as well as collectables for those who want to go the extra mile. Once you get bored of the regular campaign, there's also time trial mode for the specific levels, a flip mode where everything is upside down (which messes with you on a psychological level more than anything), and a level editor. From what I've seen so far the community isn't huge for this game anymore, but levels built into the browser can be fun, and making your own can be great as well. Overall I very much reccomend this game, so long as your aren't feint of heart.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Despite the obscure name, VVVVVV is 2D Platformer with simple graphics, simple gameplay and a simple story. When your ship crash's and your crew is scattered out in space, it's your job as the captain to round them up in order to get the ship flying again. The game's layout is in the same style as Metroid, as the map is huge and it's easy to get lost. You basically move around while defying and re-defying gravity to navigate through levels. Checkpoints are scattered everywhere and your going to need them from all of the times you die. There are 20 trinkets to find in order to unlock the jukebox or something as the music in this game is epic with its catchy tunes. Graphics are simple classic 8-bit style with bizarre looking enemies, almost feels like something out of a Commodore 64 or ZX Spectrum game. If there's one thing this game is known for, it's challenge, there is a lot of tricks and puzzles in navigating through the place and you really have to be quick on your feet and plan ahead on what to do. Overall VVVVVV is a great challenging game that feels like a throw back to the old PC games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is a hesitant recommendation. I liked the game a lot at first, but as I play more it feels like bundle fodder more than a solid game. It's short and focused on replaying for completion, but the game doesn't seem to change much in replaying. The only real reason to replay is to seek out all the achievements, but that will be an agonizing process of precision and deaths.I like how it focuses on one mechanic, flipping gravity, and plays with it in many good ways. However, that makes platforming a bit rough. Since "jumps" are based on left/right motion and timing of flips, I think the devs intentionally made left/right motion INCREDIBLY slipppery. See, you slide on every surface like you are a dog♥♥♥♥♥♥icicle, accelerating like a madman and never able to take a small step. Platforming becomes very unforgiving with smaller windows of mistakes. It IS satisfying when you complete some sections quickly, but most likely you will feel aggravated relief after you finally complete a painful section. The "Do as I say, Not as I do" section will show you how bad the sliding can be.I like the concept and style, but the execution makes it difficult to enjoy. However, it could be far worse. The short length and open paths means you can complete sections as you please (for the most part) and see the core of the game to completion with some patience. Eversion is even shorter but far more frustrating. And Yet It Moves takes the flipping idea, applies it to 4 directions, adds enemies and awkward physics, and kills you if you fall too far. AYIM is one of the games I hate the most.So, it's interesting, and done better than most. Still frustrating and handles awkwardly with the acceleration, but I hesitantly recommend if you are a platforming fan wanting something new to replay for time trials.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												VVVVVV ( 6 V's) is a short platforming game which the only thing u can do is move and walk either on the ground or on the ceiling!? The dynamics in this game looks like it was made on an NES but is actually on multiple consoles like Wii, PS3,Xbox, and PC but are in their own digital shops.You play as Viridian, a captain of his ship that was crashed in a mysterious universe called Dimension V. All of the members of the ship are teleported to diffrent areas or the dimension. You must search the entire dimension for ur lost members with ur abilty to go up or down. The achivements in this game are really hard to get especially beating no death mode since your always going to have at least 50 deaths. While ur exploring the dimension, u will encounter trinkets which dont do anything until u find 20 of them but i wont spoil it for u. Every room is quite puzzling and u might do some backtracking which is every gamers nightmare (im talking to u Metroid). This game gets 8 out of 10 because the game is really short and u can probably beat the game in less than 3 hours depending how good u are.

												I first bought 'Super Hexagon' and because I liked the basics of that game I also got this little game here (and it was on sale for 50ct...). VVVVVVIt took a while to get the background of the name. Six 'V' ? Why? But I think it is judt because in the game you have to rescue your crew after you spaceship crashed and everyone was sprayed over the map. It's an simple 2D jump and run game or no, that's wrong. It is not just a jump and run game and it is defenetly not simple. The mechanics are simple, you have a character (the captain) and you can move (left and right arrowkey) and reverse the gravety (spyce or one of the other arrows). That's it. There is a world you have to explore and you have to find the rest of the crew. Back to the name :) all crew member names are starting with a 'V' all together (you + five you have to find) six 'V's. If there is an other explenation for the Name, please let me know.The game has it's own charm. The simple grafics, the oldschool music (which is really good) and the simple gameplay are fitting together very well. And death are not bad. They are normal in this game. During the 2h campain you will die a couple of times ( I reached over 1000 times, a friend over 1500 times), so don't be frustrated if you don't get one of the extra points, just move on. Posted: January 25, 2014
												I don't usually play 'super ultra hardmodo so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ difficult that you die IRL from playing it' sort of games, but this was on sale, and so for whatever reason I thought I would give it a try. And everything worked out better than expected.VVVVVV understands an important thing that a lot of games seem to not: The difference between difficult and frustrating. And it is the former. While the puzzles and actiony bits are indeed quite hard, you have infinite lives and checkpoints are scattered everywhere, and this is actually a very good thing as it encourages you to keep trying and get better at it rather than encouraging you to quit and uninstall the game. There's also a lot to explore which 1) means you can go and try some other level if you're stuck on one, and 2) means there's enough to keep you going for a while. As of writing I haven't even finished this game (normally I wait until I've either completed a game or uninstalled it out of rage before writing a positive or negative review respectively).The story's nothing special and just serves as what is known in some communities as an "Excuse Plot", which is perfectly fine as it doesn't pretend it does have a good story and you can just ignore it. The characters are all generally likeable though, which is of course better than the alternative. As for the soundtrack, it again pleasantly surprised me as I don't usually like chiptunes but this OST somehow stands out. Pretty much none of them are tracks that I would bother turning the music off for. It's worthwhile picking up the soundtrack for general listening purposes. One negative I will say about this game though is the lack of native gamepad support so you need Xpadder or Joy2Key or what have you in order to fully enjoy it. Perhaps I'm just weird and most people can play this with a keyboard just fine, but I don't.

Posted: December 29, 2011
												If you're the type that gets hung up on little things like "graphics" or "budget"  or "titles that are pronouncable in a human language," this game probably isn't for you. If you're in it for the clever combat, hordes of brutal enemies and frenetically mounted defenses, this game isn't for you. (There's not even an attack button!) If you yearn for a masterfully paced narrative, this game probably isn't for you.Who, precisely, is this thing for?VVVVVV is, at first glance, a rudimentary platformer: with a bag of tricks consisting entirely of "run" and "jump," progress through your environment without touching any of the many things which will make you dead. A simple gravity inversion mechanic ("down" is whichever direction you're falling in) really changes things up though, and as you explore your surroundings the puzzles get steadily more challenging and engrossing. I've not played a game in recent memory that better satisfies that primal platforming itch. Highly recommended.

												Rules are simple - 3 buttons to push: -> , <-, and the "revers gravity" one, that's all, but the game is hard - just on the edge, where it doesn't break the flow or stops you.It is very energetic, it will make you panic, then will masterfuly play with your usual gaming reflexes and use them against you, this game is a great self-control tutor, but it not making you angry because your fails because checkpoints are Everywhere, plus there is not just single line of going through this tiny game, you also got some freedome.Add: I just cleared a few levels and my finger hurts! I shouted "YAAAY!" as I jumped up the celling and back, avoiding rushing things, then like "nonoNOffff.. AAgh WTisthis!? runrunRUNjump ..AAAAAAh!" all the time, can't remember me having fun of that intense while playing games for ages! 												I wouldn't say it's worth the full asking retail price of $5, but whenever it drops to a buck or so, it's worth picking up. Can get through the game from scratch in just an hour and a half easy, if your reflexes are good enough, and it'd be an hour and a half well spent.While the game sticks to the mechanic of "run around and flip gravity to get through areas" it changes the rules or environment in each of the areas in a way that keeps it interesting. Except for the "escort quest" spots that make up about 2 to 10 minutes of your time (depending on skill) I found the whole thing enjoyable. Final level's rough, and some of the shiny trinkets are asking too much, but they're not necessary.So yeah, worth the hour or two it will ask of you. Also a good candidate for speedrunning, if that's your thing!

Posted: February 10, 2013
												VVVVVV is, on the surface at least, simple in concept. You move like a standard platformer, but rather than be able to jump, you instead are able to flip gravity. What starts off as a simple concept very quickly becomes one of the most brutally hard platformers I can think of! I think the best way to describe VVVVVV is "Nintendo Hard". By this, I mean that the difficultly never feels forced or cheap, but rather 100% dependent on your skill level. Luckily, there is no set amount of lives, and the savepoints are placed in decent locations to allow you to trial and error your way past most of the deathtraps you will face. Death provides you with an instant respawn to get right back into retrying without being annoying. The game is setup as one big map, allowing to to explore in any direction as you seek out your 5 lost shipmates. The team is stranded in different areas of a giant space station, each with a unique level built around them. You can do the levels in any order you choose, or just explore around. If you are looking for a challenge, give it a go - but be warned; it's a tough one!

Posted: January 2, 2014
												VVVVVV is an incredible game and one of the best puzzle games ever.It starts by showing that all your crew has vanished and it's your job to find them, by exploring the rooms of your ship. The story isn't the selling point of the game, but it complements the game really well. It's probably the only way to give the game some logic. The twist here is that you have the power to change gravity, just by the push of a button. You can only change gravity when your in the ground/ceiling/surface or when you touch a "gravity beam". This power gives a lot of room for good game design and VVVVVV delivers it. It makes great use of this power and makes you think in ways you would never think before.But with this also comes a lot of frustration. Thankfully, VVVVVV shows that frustration may not lead to a rage quit. It's the type of frustration you get but you want to keep playing the game. Another very good thing VVVVVV delivers is it's music. The music is incredible and really brings nostalgic feelings of the 8bit era. Some of my favourite musics of this era are now from this game, which is odd, knowing this game was published in 2010.VVVVVV is a game that I highly recomend to a lot of people. Just don't expect the story to be the next final fantasy...VEREDICT: 9,5/10

Posted: December 20, 2013
												VVVVVV is a short but exciting platformer with a twist - you can't jump! That's right, a platformer without jumping. Instead, you can flip your own gravity with the press of a button to get past obstacles. It starts off as a really simple game, and I really wondered when the challenge would kick in. After the first level, you get thrown into the wide(ish) open(ish) world of dimension VVVVVV, where you have to search for your friends. Each friend is in another dungeon, and boy those dungeons are hard! They are challenging, but manageable. Never did I find myself stuck at one spot for too long, but every dungeon had me die quite a few times on my first playthrough. It's fun to replay the dungeons, even though they get easier as you play them more. You can really master the dungeons, which is extremely fun to do. I would definitely recommend this game to everyone who loves platforming as much as I do.

												Well bought for $1.If you are willing to give yourself to play this hard game,then you should try this,the game before Super Hexagon release,This game is a Platformer game,but in twisted way,which bring to originality,which you can flip your character to upside-down,your mission is to rescue your buddies which trapped into other area because of malfunctioning teleportation,So far,the game looks like a Commondore-64 Game but can`t be run it,only for windows :PThe game is brutally hard for the first timer due to how the map design was,which some of the area full of spikes,traps,and more of it,that cause harm to your character.The soundtrack really blends the game,which is enjoyable to hear a good music playing together with stages,you can also buy  the music by getting a Tokens which assumes that it could be hidden anywhere.How to get it?Well you have to find out :)Anyway,this game is fun to play,and expect to see rage if you can`t beat the stage,i dare you :)Score : 9.0 / 10

Posted: December 20, 2013
												VVVVVV is a short but exciting platformer with a twist - you can't jump! That's right, a platformer without jumping. Instead, you can flip your own gravity with the press of a button to get past obstacles. It starts off as a really simple game, and I really wondered when the challenge would kick in. After the first level, you get thrown into the wide(ish) open(ish) world of dimension VVVVVV, where you have to search for your friends. Each friend is in another dungeon, and boy those dungeons are hard! They are challenging, but manageable. Never did I find myself stuck at one spot for too long, but every dungeon had me die quite a few times on my first playthrough. It's fun to replay the dungeons, even though they get easier as you play them more. You can really master the dungeons, which is extremely fun to do. I would definitely recommend this game to everyone who loves platforming as much as I do.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I wouldn't say it's worth the full asking retail price of $5, but whenever it drops to a buck or so, it's worth picking up. Can get through the game from scratch in just an hour and a half easy, if your reflexes are good enough, and it'd be an hour and a half well spent.While the game sticks to the mechanic of "run around and flip gravity to get through areas" it changes the rules or environment in each of the areas in a way that keeps it interesting. Except for the "escort quest" spots that make up about 2 to 10 minutes of your time (depending on skill) I found the whole thing enjoyable. Final level's rough, and some of the shiny trinkets are asking too much, but they're not necessary.So yeah, worth the hour or two it will ask of you. Also a good candidate for speedrunning, if that's your thing!

Posted: December 11, 2013
												This is probably my favorite game. No "if"s "and"s or "butt"s about it. I don't usually like replaying games that have story lines(i.e. Half Life). But this game I can play over and over and it never gets old. I also love how challenging it is, a lot of games I've played I could just win no problem. Even though this game has infinite lives, that's honestly better. Because you can try over and over at one thing you keep dying at(which causes a little more frustration sometimes).However, I do have a single complaint on behalf of mac users. This game does not have an in game volume control, and since mac os does not have the equivalent of "Windows Volume Mixer". The sound track is at what the game sets it at. So if you like your own music(which you should just listen to VVVVVV's music, pretty good), or you talk to people while playing, you may want to get a third party volume control.

When your Path is finally Complete, you can take a moment to Pause, and look back at the Plenary journey that you have finished, and you might become quite the Popular Potpourri for defeating this incredibly challenging game! This game is so brilliant, you must purchase it immediately! What are you Waiting for? VVVVVV!
