Posted: December 27, 2014
												I want to start by saying that VVVVVV is a rather difficult game. It's tricky, it requires some really hard timing, and at times it can be extremely frustrating. (Oh, also, seizure warning!)But the game makes it work, and it's absolutely genius. It's got an 8-bit, retro style and that beautiful creative touch that every indie game needs. The main mechanic, while not necessarily something that's never been done before, it certainly used cleverly and uniquely. Not only that, but the quirky storyline and amazing soundtrack keep the whole thing interesting and worthwhile even when you feel like pulling your hair out over a level you can't get past.It's evil, and I love it.Also, it has a level editor, which in my eyes doubles the value of any already good game. A fully featured one at that.10/10, would brave The Tower again.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Rules are simple - 3 buttons to push: -> , <-, and the "revers gravity" one, that's all, but the game is hard - just on the edge, where it doesn't break the flow or stops you.It is very energetic, it will make you panic, then will masterfuly play with your usual gaming reflexes and use them against you, this game is a great self-control tutor, but it not making you angry because your fails because checkpoints are Everywhere, plus there is not just single line of going through this tiny game, you also got some freedome.Add: I just cleared a few levels and my finger hurts! I shouted "YAAAY!" as I jumped up the celling and back, avoiding rushing things, then like "nonoNOffff.. AAgh WTisthis!? runrunRUNjump ..AAAAAAh!" all the time, can't remember me having fun of that intense while playing games for ages!  It allows you to travel back in time and experience that precious childish excitement and fun we had playing console games back then and even more, that seemed to be lost for good, this game - is pure minimalistic fun!

Posted: December 27, 2011
												I did complete this game (this does not happen to every game I play) and enjoyed it very much. First of all, the music is GREAT and complements whatever is happening on the screen very nicely. I am not a big fan of chiptune music, but this OST has some really catchy tunes and is of extremely good quality. The gameplay is very solid, just as the visuals it is retro-styled. However, due to very good placement of save-points VVVVVV is not as severly punishing as those games, by which it was obviously inspired. The storyline is not really important and does not add anything to the game. The graphics do the trick of making the game look really old-school and reminding me of many games I played in the past. I would by no means call them "spectacular", though. Overall the game gives you a good experience, which is fun, sometimes frustrating, but still makes you feel proud of yourself for accomplishing the obstacles without becoming excessively enraging.

												Summers in Louisiana are hot.Last night I had a dream that Barack Obama had to move into my house. It turned out he was an alright guy, but he was incredibly naive and didn't really know what was going on in the world. He said he was pretty much just hired as an actor as president and that there were other people running things behind the scenes. He was really big on drinking "soda pop" and inventing secret handshakes.Later on I was forced by the government to retake my senior year of highschool because of some legal loophole, with Barack Obama frequently accompanying me against my will. At some point Legion from Mass Effect enrolled at my school and suddenly he became pregnant. Legion's child looked like he would if he was a Chinese knock-off, and was kind of a prick.

Posted: December 29, 2011
												If you're the type that gets hung up on little things like "graphics" or "budget"  or "titles that are pronouncable in a human language," this game probably isn't for you. If you're in it for the clever combat, hordes of brutal enemies and frenetically mounted defenses, this game isn't for you. (There's not even an attack button!) If you yearn for a masterfully paced narrative, this game probably isn't for you.Who, precisely, is this thing for?VVVVVV is, at first glance, a rudimentary platformer: with a bag of tricks consisting entirely of "run" and "jump," progress through your environment without touching any of the many things which will make you dead. A simple gravity inversion mechanic ("down" is whichever direction you're falling in) really changes things up though, and as you explore your surroundings the puzzles get steadily more challenging and engrossing. I've not played a game in recent memory that better satisfies that primal platforming itch. Highly recommended.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												One of the most delightful games I have played in a long time. VVVVVV goes further than just look retro, and the reverse gravity ability (instead of jumping) goes to great lengths to make it both enjoyable, and challenging. With a Metroid-vania style of map exploration system, this is one of the few games that actually makes me want to explore every nook and cranny. The music is a retro, 8-bit style delight, and the checkpoints are vast, which means you get back on your feet quickly. The game grows on you, and as you complete the game and find every secret, you feel a great satisfaction. Definitely a game for the retro platformers (some challenges can get quite difficult) but still a great game, even if you're not a fan of 2D platformers.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												One of the cleverest, funnest platformers I've ever played, but sadly also one of the shortest, with you being able to pass through the last room and complete a run through in under an hour. That is not to detract from it, it is a magnificent game, where you will die alot, with stragetically places checkpoints to throw you right back into those tiny, pixelated spikes.To combat the short play through, VVVVVV has some tricks up it's sleeves. You will unlock Time Trials of stages you've completed, be able to return to the intermission levels, you can scower the world for all twenty trinkets, and even play the full game over with the entire world flipped upside down, which for some reason makes it more difficult.Short, incredibly sweet and fairly cheap. Can't go wrong.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												VVVVVV is a charming, short, hard, funny, and gravitational experience.In VVVVVV you play as Captain Viridian.  Captain Viridian has to save his freinds (Which all of their start with the letter V for some reason.) because you crash-landed in a collapsing dimension or something like that.  Oh yeah, and they're lost.In VVVVVV you don't jump, but you CHANGE GRAVITY!!  :O  Ok, ok, other games did it first, but VVVVVV just PERFECTS it!  It's the right amount of speed, and you can't air surf, giving balance between the player and the level design.  And then there's invincibility.  You can turn this thing on AT WILL!!!  I recommend using the ability in 1 or 2 rooms.And thats VVVVVV!  It was a great experience from start to finish (Even if it IS 1 hr.) and I HIGHLY recommend It!Oh yeah, and it has some rockin' tunes.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Yet another retro platformer with apparent pixels and chiptunes music? Yes, but it is a perfectly crafted piece of fun. The difficulty is impressive but the checkpoints are numerous and well-placed for the die-die again-die many more times then succeed approach. The music is memorable and there is a good replay value (time trials, post-game challenges, collectibles...). So indulge yourself in the adventures of a captain searching for his crew in a deadly world.There is even a level editor (with some samples by indie devs) if you want to make other people suffer some more. Too bad the Steam integration has not been thought of (the overlay does not work and there is no way to share through Steam's workshop. Still this is a very minor complaint for a great little game.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												VVVVVV is a fun, forgiving, hard, indie game from 2010 that's well worth $5 at the most. It's a two hour experience (if you're good) that provides plenty of replayability to all the achievement hunters out there. The controls are easy to pick up, but can be very sensitive. The game tests your patience, so if you don't like games like Super Meat Boy or The Binding of Isaac then this game isn't your type of game. However, if you like a little challenge in your life, then pick this game up. It has catchy chiptune music, a decent story, and a fun world to explore. It gets a 7/10 from me.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Without a doubt, VVVVVV is one of the hardest platformers around. It's also one of the best of its class.Don't let it's simple unsuspecting appearance fool you. Beneath the inviting Commodore 64-esque visuals lay a game of absolute terror. Not the usual sort of horror, mind you; it doesn't make you jump or mess with your mind. No, this game terrifies you with its sheer intense level design, demanding nothing less but total perfection to conquer its gantlet of doom. To best this game you need fortuity, to be able to hold steadfast in the face of adversity, and some crazy fast reflexes.I can't say enough good things about VVVVVV. It's Terry Cavanagh's best game to date, and one of the best and most difficult platformers I've ever played. If you have any interest in challenging platformers whatsoever, you'd be doing yourself a disservice not to pick up VVVVVV.

Posted: May 22, 2012
												VVVVVV is a great platformer and puzzle game with difficult levels that make you want to try over and over again. This is in no way a bad game. The classic retro style may not have the best graphics but that doesn't change anything. The music and tough level design fit well together and the story is small but awesome. You basically are Captain Viridian in some strange place after your ship crashed and need to explore and find the rest of your crew. I highly recommend this to fans of platformers, puzzle and retro style games. If you want to get into platformers this might be a challenge for you so try something easier like Mario or Kirby then maybe move on to games like this or Super Meat Boy. But if your a new gamer looking for a challenge then you should definitely try this out.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Disregard everybody saying this takes 2-4 hours to beat. I did it in less than an hour in my first playthrough, and slowly cut time from there. There are 20 trinkets to collect and if you do that it will take longer, but most of them aren't too out of the way. There are two trinkets that together will take twice as long as it did to beat the game. It's worth it though. You may rage some but the game flows smoothly and constantly, so you can die 15 times in the span of a minute and still feel like you're making progress. Going by the achievement statistics, less than 10% of players managed to beat this game, which is in part a testification to its difficulty but honestly I think it's mostly that this is not everyone's game. If you like platformers, it doesn't get much better than this, but if you prefer 3D games that focus more on storyline than gameplay (nothing wrong with that), then you could pick a better game to start playing 2D again. Note: there are at times a lot of moving colors onscreen, but it's generally monochromatic - if you have epilepsy and are the photosensitive type you should be careful with this purchase, but know that it's not that bad and probably won't do anything (it's nothing at all like Super Hexagon).tl;dr If you're bad at 2D platformers and want to get better, buy this game but be ready to rage. If you like platformers, this game is amazing.

												Very good game, but I was never able to finish it.  I couldn't find the right way after rescuing the majority of the other people.Worth the whole dollar thirty i bought it for on sale for sure.Probably would've bought it for 5 dollars too.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												Play VVVVVV. It's for Windows by Terry the man. It's amazing. I beat it, almost 100% now, a while back, but I still play it for time to time because it's fun. It's an action puzzle game where you play as a lost captain trying to find six crew members. You move around a big map and get crewmembers by going into dungeons and reaching the end. There are disks you can collect and it is really an exciting game. It's called VVVVVV because that's what the spikes look like, and you walk normally (left and right) and hit V to flip. Pretty simple, but the game style is beautiful and it is entertaining.

Posted: March 4, 2013
												An excellent and very challenging platformer with awesome 8-bit retro graphics. Excellent responsiveness to controls, great soundtrack, also as if getting all the trinkets wasn't hard enough, you get even more insane challenges (such as completing the game without dying) once you collect all of the trinkets. This game suits any kind of hardcore gamer: speedrunners, completionists, you will all enjoy it.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												This was my first game I owned on Steam. I'm happy to say that this game is well deserving of that statistic. It's unique gameplay and amazing soundtrack make this one of my favorite indie platformers ever.Story:You assume the role of Captain Viridian, the cyan-colored protagonist whose spaceship has become trapped in an alternative dimension thanks to dimensional interference. Viridian must now explore the dimension to find his five lost crew members and the cause of the interference.Gameplay:This is a platformer that feels unique. The biggest difference between this game and other platformers is that instead of jumping, you invert gravity, causing Viridian to flip between upside-down and right-side-up. You'll have to flip gravity and walk across both floors and ceilings to make your way through the game. It's an open-world game. It can be a bit difficult to navigate your way around even if you're using the map to help you, but this never felt like too much of a problem. There's also 20 trinkets to collect for those that want more out of the game.Conclusion:If you're a fan of 2D platformers, this game is definitely worth checking out. The soundtrack is amazing. and the gameplay is even better. You'll find yourself raging at some parts, but overall it makes for a fun indie game. It's biggest negative would be that it's rather short. It only took me about four to five hours to complete the story. The story wasn't anything special, but it was sufficient. The gameplay and soundtrack is what gives this game it's charm and makes it well worth the $5 that it costs.

Posted: October 30, 2013
												A super simple, super tough, super fun platformer. You will love dying 50 times until getting past the current stage to run into...another...obstacle... DEATH BEEP

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Ahhh VVVVVV. Now this is a fun little indie game, with some neat visuals and pretty sweet music. And at the price it is, has a good length and is pretty challenging. So pick it up and enjoy some retro platforming!

Posted: December 27, 2011
												I did complete this game (this does not happen to every game I play) and enjoyed it very much. First of all, the music is GREAT and complements whatever is happening on the screen very nicely. I am not a big fan of chiptune music, but this OST has some really catchy tunes and is of extremely good quality. The gameplay is very solid, just as the visuals it is retro-styled. However, due to very good placement of save-points VVVVVV is not as severly punishing as those games, by which it was obviously inspired. The storyline is not really important and does not add anything to the game. The graphics do the trick of making the game look really old-school and reminding me of many games I played in the past. I would by no means call them "spectacular", though. Overall the game gives you a good experience, which is fun, sometimes frustrating, but still makes you feel proud of yourself for accomplishing the obstacles without becoming excessively enraging.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												I want to start by saying that VVVVVV is a rather difficult game. It's tricky, it requires some really hard timing, and at times it can be extremely frustrating. (Oh, also, seizure warning!)But the game makes it work, and it's absolutely genius. It's got an 8-bit, retro style and that beautiful creative touch that every indie game needs. The main mechanic, while not necessarily something that's never been done before, it certainly used cleverly and uniquely. Not only that, but the quirky storyline and amazing soundtrack keep the whole thing interesting and worthwhile even when you feel like pulling your hair out over a level you can't get past.It's evil, and I love it.Also, it has a level editor, which in my eyes doubles the value of any already good game. A fully featured one at that.10/10, would brave The Tower again.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I wouldn't say it's worth the full asking retail price of $5, but whenever it drops to a buck or so, it's worth picking up. Can get through the game from scratch in just an hour and a half easy, if your reflexes are good enough, and it'd be an hour and a half well spent.While the game sticks to the mechanic of "run around and flip gravity to get through areas" it changes the rules or environment in each of the areas in a way that keeps it interesting. Except for the "escort quest" spots that make up about 2 to 10 minutes of your time (depending on skill) I found the whole thing enjoyable. Final level's rough, and some of the shiny trinkets are asking too much, but they're not necessary.So yeah, worth the hour or two it will ask of you. Also a good candidate for speedrunning, if that's your thing!

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Difficult challenging game, i got this for 50 cents so it was more than worth it.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												Fun gameplay; nice retro art style; GREAT music; and has just the right amount of challenge. The only downside is that it's a bit too short(1hr or less to beat).

Posted: June 23, 2014
												A great game. A wide variety of levels along with variety in gameplay keep the game interesting and fun. The music is also pretty great. It also allows for the play of user-made levels and has a built-in level editor. It's definitely worth the $4.99 it costs.

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Wow, this game is so good. I my self dislike platformers especially harder ones, but the controls in this game are so good its never felt the games fault that you died. Not to mention the amazing music. I would recomend this game so many times to everyone.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												VVVVVV is an incredible game and one of the best puzzle games ever.It starts by showing that all your crew has vanished and it's your job to find them, by exploring the rooms of your ship. The story isn't the selling point of the game, but it complements the game really well. It's probably the only way to give the game some logic. The twist here is that you have the power to change gravity, just by the push of a button. You can only change gravity when your in the ground/ceiling/surface or when you touch a "gravity beam". This power gives a lot of room for good game design and VVVVVV delivers it. It makes great use of this power and makes you think in ways you would never think before.But with this also comes a lot of frustration. Thankfully, VVVVVV shows that frustration may not lead to a rage quit. It's the type of frustration you get but you want to keep playing the game. Another very good thing VVVVVV delivers is it's music. The music is incredible and really brings nostalgic feelings of the 8bit era. Some of my favourite musics of this era are now from this game, which is odd, knowing this game was published in 2010.VVVVVV is a game that I highly recomend to a lot of people. Just don't expect the story to be the next final fantasy...VEREDICT: 9,5/10

Posted: January 2, 2014
												What a wonderful love letter to the age of 8-bit gaming! VVVVVV looks like an old Commodore 64/Atari 800 game, but feels like a modern platformer. The gameplay is wonderfully simplistic - challenging without being frustrating. The dialogue, controls and timings are all exemplary. The music is special. This is retro gaming at its very best and is definitely worth purchasing. The only thing I don't like about the game is the name. Six vees? Vee, vee, vee, vee, vee, vee? Terrible name, great game!

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Fun game if you like the retro feel and unlimited lives, however the movement in the game is sudden and the slight "slide" you have when you land or moving through the air is slightly annoying since barely tapping a direction usually ends up with you moving a lot farther then you intended.Tons of checkpoints which makes dying not that big of an issue, but way too many trick jumps for my liking.With that said I do recommend the game, its a good way to kill some time.

Posted: August 15, 2012
												Up and down. Simply amazing how deep of a story and world came from these simple mechanics. the graphics feel like the kind you'd find on a DOS game, and that is just fine. the sheer depth of level design is stunning. each room is different from the one before, but they all fit together to give you an incredibly dense "mini-universe".

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												One of the best games I've ever played. Not only aesthetically pleasing, rich in environments and elaborate in the soundtrack, it can also offer you quite a challenge if you decide to pursue the trinkets.VVVVVV really teaches an important lesson about making games: you don't always need complex and elaborate mechanics to create a pleasing experience.It's more crucial to make something fun to play, a little crazy, and polish out all (or most) quirks. All of this is present into the game, and I can tell for sure the developers really loved it themselves before shipping it to us.

Posted: December 30, 2011
												Simplicity usually makes or breaks a game for me. In this case, it's definitely the former. The mere addition of gravity-reversing mechanic in what otherwise would be a Metroid-lookalike created a whole new experience. A challenging game with an amazing soundtrack, that only falls short in terms of length.

Posted: December 11, 2013
												This is probably my favorite game. No "if"s "and"s or "butt"s about it. I don't usually like replaying games that have story lines(i.e. Half Life). But this game I can play over and over and it never gets old. I also love how challenging it is, a lot of games I've played I could just win no problem. Even though this game has infinite lives, that's honestly better. Because you can try over and over at one thing you keep dying at(which causes a little more frustration sometimes).However, I do have a single complaint on behalf of mac users. This game does not have an in game volume control, and since mac os does not have the equivalent of "Windows Volume Mixer". The sound track is at what the game sets it at. So if you like your own music(which you should just listen to VVVVVV's music, pretty good), or you talk to people while playing, you may want to get a third party volume control.

												VVVVVV is a throwback to the sidescrollers of old, with elements of Super Mario Bros, I Wanna Be the Guy, and Portal. Posted: August 21, 2014
												The controls in VVVVVV are very tight and responsive, the gameplay is challenging, but it never feels unfair. The soundtrack is a fun retro-themed set of beats. Very catchy, too. The graphics are also very nostalgic with some trippy backgrounds.My only gripe with VVVVVV is the fact that the main campaign is too short, lasting only around 3 hours. However, to combat this, many other things are added such as player levels, a level editor and more features I won't spoil.9/10

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Yet another retro platformer with apparent pixels and chiptunes music? Yes, but it is a perfectly crafted piece of fun. The difficulty is impressive but the checkpoints are numerous and well-placed for the die-die again-die many more times then succeed approach. The music is memorable and there is a good replay value (time trials, post-game challenges, collectibles...). So indulge yourself in the adventures of a captain searching for his crew in a deadly world.There is even a level editor (with some samples by indie devs) if you want to make other people suffer some more. Too bad the Steam integration has not been thought of (the overlay does not work and there is no way to share through Steam's workshop. Still this is a very minor complaint for a great little game.

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Long story short, I can recommend this game to anyone who enjoys difficult but doable puzzle platforming, and perhaps even a bit of exploration tastes too. If you like 100%ing games.VVVVVV is challenging, but quite fair, most of the time. Uh....I guess there isn't really much of a long story. If you can't tell by the screenshots, the game has a visual style reflecting older game systems such as ...well, something a tad more powerful than an atari, perhaps. The era between atari and NES is lost to me. But yeah, really retro graphical style, but it works to its advantage since it leaves less of a busy screen thus letting you focus better. Except one area, which brings me to something else:IF YOU ARE VULNERABLE TO SEIZURES, and whatnot, DO NOT GET THIS. There's one area of the game that just messes with your eyes too nasty-like that left me feeling sick after playing. That's the only real downer, I have to say.Musically, it's great. It's easy on the ears, some reminds me of Toki Tori on the gameboy color with it's bleeps an' bloops,  but it's chiptune stuff so if you're into to that or not, there you go.So, if you like teasing your brain, are not able to seize out, and are fine with trying over and over at things many many times, then get this game, because it was well worth what I spent, I tell ya.

												Excellent game. Very simple mechanics but challenging regardless; the game itself is quite short but there's plenty of replayability, with time trials and collectibles to find, plus dozens of user created levels. The soundtrack is also absolutely fantastic, one of the best I've heard in a while. There's definitely a huge sense of accomplishment when you complete a hard section that takes many tries to do. Posted: July 4, 2011
												Like an oldschool ZX Spectrum platformer, brutal and punishing yet remarkably addictive. And the soundtrack rules. :3 Great game.

Posted: December 27, 2010
												Platforming with a twist. VVVVVV is an excellent example of a good platformer that has been made better by adding an original, interesting core game mechanic. In VVVVVV, you play as Captain Viridian who must rescue his crew after a disaster nearly destroys his ship. Traveling all around a strange new universe called "VVVVVV", you must rescue each crew member in their own zone of the map. Each new zone introduces a new game mechanic such as moving maps, bouncy ropes, and NPC co-op.VVVVVV's system of introducing new mechanics allows you to adjust to each challenge before entering the last stages of the game which require you to navigate maps containing every mechanic simultaneously. This isn't an easy game, but not too hard to beat if you're persistent. Many of the most challenging puzzles are previously-optional challenges which are required to reach a treasure. Veni Vidi Vici. After completing the main story and collecting every treasure, you receive a special reward.

												VVVVVV is a 2D platformer with an amazing soundtrack and addictive gameplay. Be prepared to spend the next couple of hours  flipping from floor to floor and avoiding death to chiptune music.

Posted: March 13, 2013
												An enjoyable game that lasts around 4 hours give or take depending on skill. From the moment you step out of the tutorial you are able to explore the entire world using your single ability to flip gravity. Deriving its name from the numerous spikes that litter the world, you traverse room to room avoiding various obsticles by timing your inversions of gravity. The controls are tight and the soundtrack is delightfuly catchy. Fans of games like Metroid or Castlevania will enjoy the exploration present in the game.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												An absolutely terrific experience, this game shows no need to insert unnecessary gimmicks or elements into any of its standard levels. Instead, Cavanagh's VVVVVV opts to take its core, the gravity-flip mechanic, to its extreme, easing players from simple early levels to some of the most rewarding puzzles and stages ever in the later game and maintaining use of infinite lives and checkpoints throughout so as not to cheat the player. The core "story" (the plot is relatively unimportant) can be finished in two hours or less, but time trials, collectibles, and a sense of exploration that recalls the original Zelda or even Adventure makes this game worth playing over and over again. Forever.Also, the music is fantastic. So yeah, just buy this already.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Without a doubt, VVVVVV is one of the hardest platformers around. It's also one of the best of its class.Don't let it's simple unsuspecting appearance fool you. Beneath the inviting Commodore 64-esque visuals lay a game of absolute terror. Not the usual sort of horror, mind you; it doesn't make you jump or mess with your mind. No, this game terrifies you with its sheer intense level design, demanding nothing less but total perfection to conquer its gantlet of doom. To best this game you need fortuity, to be able to hold steadfast in the face of adversity, and some crazy fast reflexes.I can't say enough good things about VVVVVV. It's Terry Cavanagh's best game to date, and one of the best and most difficult platformers I've ever played. If you have any interest in challenging platformers whatsoever, you'd be doing yourself a disservice not to pick up VVVVVV.

Posted: April 25, 2013
												Flips, flips, and more ♥♥♥♥ing flips. Think of what things can't flip. Trains. Trains can't flip, they're on rails. If they could they'd be rollercoasters. VVVVVV is what you get when you get a train, and then decide to place wheels on the roof, and tracks above it, then flip earth's gravity away from the core. Makes sense? Sure as hell doesn't, but it makes for some awesome gameplay. People use this game to exemplify stereotypical lazy indie game graphics, but ♥♥♥♥ them, because they probably played with their sound muted or with a stick up their♥♥♥♥♥ 10/10 GOTYAY Forik #1 pick of the millenium would replay infinitely, since it only takes me like an hour to beat anyways.PS: This is a really good game

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Without a doubt, VVVVVV is one of the hardest platformers around. It's also one of the best of its class.Don't let it's simple unsuspecting appearance fool you. Beneath the inviting Commodore 64-esque visuals lay a game of absolute terror. Not the usual sort of horror, mind you; it doesn't make you jump or mess with your mind. No, this game terrifies you with its sheer intense level design, demanding nothing less but total perfection to conquer its gantlet of doom. To best this game you need fortuity, to be able to hold steadfast in the face of adversity, and some crazy fast reflexes.I can't say enough good things about VVVVVV. It's Terry Cavanagh's best game to date, and one of the best and most difficult platformers I've ever played. If you have any interest in challenging platformers whatsoever, you'd be doing yourself a disservice not to pick up VVVVVV.

Posted: April 25, 2013
												Flips, flips, and more ♥♥♥♥ing flips. Think of what things can't flip. Trains. Trains can't flip, they're on rails. If they could they'd be rollercoasters. VVVVVV is what you get when you get a train, and then decide to place wheels on the roof, and tracks above it, then flip earth's gravity away from the core. Makes sense? Sure as hell doesn't, but it makes for some awesome gameplay. People use this game to exemplify stereotypical lazy indie game graphics, but ♥♥♥♥ them, because they probably played with their sound muted or with a stick up their♥♥♥♥♥ 10/10 GOTYAY Forik #1 pick of the millenium would replay infinitely, since it only takes me like an hour to beat anyways.PS: This is a really good game

Posted: February 20
												TL;DR, it's an overall pretty good platforming game, and worth checking out.So, overall, I like VVVVVV. It was an enjoyable experience with an awesome soundtrack and a simple, yet creative mechanic that a lot is done with. But it's not a perfect game. It does have some problems. The smaller ones are very small, to be fair, such as the overall length of the game. It is a short game. I beat it in a little over an hour. Granted, the length is up in the air, depending on your overall skill at the game itself, but it's still a short game. So, if you are looking for a longer game, this might not be for you. Another problem with this game, is the "escort" missions. The distance that those following you follow at isn't ever defined, and that can often lead to frustating moments in the more difficult sections of the escort missions.Now, the biggest problem I had with the game is the controls. Your character slides a fair bit, which wouldn't be the biggest issue in most games, but in this game, when you have to be very precise in your movements, you can often slide off the sides of platforms if you land a little too close to the edge. Early on, this is very unnoticable, as it's a little easier overall, but later in the game, it often leads to a large number of seemingly unfair deaths.But, besides those main issues, this game has a lot of good going for it. Interesting use of mechanics, amazing music that keeps you hyped throughout the game, and a great feeling of success each time you beat a level. If I had to give this a number rathing, it's say it's about a 7/10 game.

												A lot of games, you play for 10 hours at a time, and it feels like 5 minutes.  With this game, it's quite the opposite.  You'll be doing a puzzle that, when figured out, takes approximately 6 seconds, but you feel like you've been trying it for hours.  VVVVVV will make you laugh.  VVVVVV will make you cry.  VVVVVV will make you check the room for young children before spewing profanities unknown to man.  Overall, a cunning challenge with a bumpin' soundtrack and cool graphics!

Posted: October 5, 2015
												VVVVVV is a platformer with a simple twist: you don't jump, you flip gravity upside-down.The first thing you will notice is the super low-fi visual style of the game. Plenty of indie titles have a classic 2D retro look that reminds the player of the game consoles of the late 80s and early 90s, but VVVVVV takes it to a new level, evoking the games of the Commodore 64. The simple sprites, eight color pallette, and bold, minimalist levels create a game that is simple to understand and as distinctive as they come.VVVVVV also rocks one of the best soundtracks out there, with a chiptune soundtrack courtesy of Magnus Pålsson that infuses the game with an energy that enhances the experience in a brilliant way.Unlike the classic games it resembles, VVVVVV presents its simple story within the game itself (instead of in the manual). You are Captain Viridian, and your ship has been caught in a dimensional anomaly. You are tasked with rescuing each of your crew members, who have been scattered throughout the strange dimension. After finding each crewmember, you will bring them back to the ship, get a tiny piece of information about your situation, and head back out for another. It's a simple premise that serves the game well enough.Using the gravity-flipping mechanic, you traverse a sprawling 2D map in every direction. The most common obstacle you must avoid are the spikes from which the game takes its name (they look like a row of Vs). Other obstacles may be bouncing shapes or even cannons that shoot words at you. Death is a common occurance in VVVVVV, but dying will simply cause you to respawn at the last checkpoint you tagged, which are abundant and typically placed at the start of each room or challenge. The respawn is instantaneous, which gives VVVVVV the same fun, forgiving feel as Super Meat Boy. A challenge may take you dozens of tries to complete, but you will feel like you are learning, improving, and progressing throughout. Even at its most challenging (and VVVVVV can be brutally difficult at times), I never felt frustrated by the experience.The map is also divided into different regions, distinguished by a new environment color. These zones each have a signiture mechanic that alters the way you interact with the level. All are intuitive, and they bring enough variety to keep the experience fresh for the duration of the game.On the whole, VVVVVV is a game that succeeds at every level. It is simple, elegant, and amazingly fun. Not many games offer challenge without frustration quite like this. Even if platformers aren't your favorite genre, I still highly recommend VVVVVV.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												My first playthrough of "VVVVVV" took me 2.75 hours. In that time, I died 1070 times. (The game helpfully keeps count). That's 6.5x a minute, or just shy of once every 9 1/3 seconds. Little wonder there's a section of the game titled "Your Bitter Tears ... Delicious." (In my darkest moments, there were times that I thought a better title would have been "OMG F--K THIS GAME!!!!1") And yet in the end, I enjoyed myself quite a lot. Really, I swear.The basic idea: flip, bounce, and ceiling-walk to avoid spikes and other assorted 8-bit hazards. Rescue fellow space-crew members. Enjoy the awesome chiptune soundtrack. Try not to ragequit when the going gets tough, as it often does (though never game-killingly so). The mechanics and presentation are simple; the skill needed to solve the various environmental puzzles and execute the precision jumps are a bit more advanced. Luckily the game is consistently fun and cheekily aware of its own difficulty, so that it remains not just enjoyable but likable throughout.There's a plot, I guess. Something to do with a spaceship and a dimensional shambler. A running joke throughout the game is that almost none of the characters even claim to understand what's going on, either. We're all just here for the flipping, right?Recommended. Just pack some Xanax.

												This game has a simle premise - you jump over obstacles, you simply reverse gravity.  And that little change makes this a phenomenal example of how to take the age-old platformer genre, and simply turn it into something amazing.

Posted: July 23, 2011
												Recommended to hardcore oldschool gamers only!Best platformer I played in the last 15 years (yes you have to go back in time to find something better!).Level design is brilliant and evil at the same time, but it won't lead to (excessive) frustration, because when you die you immediately respawn without any downtime and you don't have a limited number of lives so essentially you can die hundreds of times. I died 762 times to complete the game!The soundtrack is so beautiful and together with the graphics brings back so many memories that I bought it as soon as I completed the game: go to http://www.souleye.se/pppppp to buy MP3s or FLACs.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												VVVVVV is an old-school-charmer built on two simple principles: you can invert gravity, and if you touch a spike you die. Sounds simple enough! It's that simple premise that makes the game so easy to pick up, and also so easy to wedge a pickax through your keyboard. Fans of VERY old-school games will probably enjoy this most of all. It's surprisingly longer than you'd expect (took me 2 hours to complete, in short 25-minute bursts, with full grief counseling sessions in between), and the music is absolutely ROCKING. Definitely recommended when on sale (I picked it up for 50 cents, an absolute steal).When you beat it, wear it like a badge of honor, just like you did when you beat Battletoads on the NES.

Posted: April 2, 2016
												Voilà! In view, a humble vaudevillian veteran cast vicariously as both victim and villain by the vicissitudes of Fate. This visage, no mere veneer of vanity, is a vestige of the vox populi, now vacant, vanished. However, this valourous visitation of a bygone vexation stands vivified and has vowed to vanquish these venal and virulent vermin vanguarding vice and vouchsafing the violently vicious and voracious violation of volition! The only verdict is vengeance; a vendetta held as a votive, not in vain, for the value and veracity of such shall one day vindicate the vigilant and the virtuous. Verily, this vichyssoise of verbiage veers most verbose, so let me simply add that it's my very good honour to meet you and you may call me V.VVVVVV is a fabulous pixel-style game, created by super-addictive Super Hexagon's creator Terry Cavanagh. It can be considered both enjoyable and annoyingly difficult. I love the plot, the names of those levels, along with the symbolic enemies....(I'll finish this comment several days later)

Posted: April 5, 2015
												How do you make an amazing game based on one mechanic? By making VVVVVV, of course. The concept of this game is that you can flip gravity with the press of a key, and you'll end up on the ceiling. The game uses this idea exceptionally, with lots of fun areas and puzzles to explore. With its simple graphics and awesome soundtrack, this is one of the best indie games of our time.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Pretty good game, with about 2 hours of gameplay if you don't go for the secrets.This game involves the use of your ability to reverse gravity to traverse dangerous levels. You can only switch gravity while on the ground (or ceiling), though, meaning you can't change direction while in mid-air.You are a space captain and your team is flying through space. Suddenly, the crew is evacuated due to a catastrophe, and you must find your way back as well as save the other members of your crew. The gameplay is solid, but it gets frustrating after about ten deaths in the same room (or the same checkpoint). That isn't to say this game is bad. It's an excellent indie game that everyone should at least try, especially if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2013
												This is amongst one of the best examples that graphics do not make a game what it actually is. VVVVVV is amongst my favourite platformers of all time, it's simple yet charming pixel graphicstyle gives the game it's own "uniqueness" and I can probably say that it makes it feel  like a really old game. The sountrack is AMAZING and it features some of the best chiptunes tracks I ever seen on a game and I simply love it. The story is nothing special, atleast for me. What makes VVVVVV an excellent game it's his simple yet well polished flipping mechanic along with some optional exploration and high precision platforming sections which might make the game abit frustrating, this is definitely a great platformer and a great game, buy it, support the dev, play it, ENJOY IT!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												8.5/10VVVVVV brings few ideas to the table. It has a simple control scheme, a simple art style, and a forgetable story yet this lets the game explore and perfect gameplay. Each level has a slight twist on the basic game mechanic, switching gravity. One level is autoscrolling and another has trampolines, for example. These different level ideas allow for the game not to get stale.This game is hard. You will die and die a lot, especially if you are hoping to get the 20 collectables. I died over 2000 times in my first playthrough. Luckily, the punishment for death is nearly non-existant with many checkpoints scattered throughout the levels. This game feels fair with its deaths and most of the time when I died I would blame myself not the game. This game requires trial and error to grasp the level design and mechanics but completing this game is a rewarding task.The game is relatively short yet there is some things to do after you beat the game, including time trials and flip mode. Also, with user created levels, the game could extend indefinately.Overall, retro fans that enjoy a little difficulty will enjoy VVVVVV. The game does away with flashy components and goes back to NES era games. The level design was incredibly well thought out and therefore this game gets my strong recommendation.8.5/10

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is an absolute masterpiece. Very few games can keep people playing after dying hundreds of times. I'm guessing that it has something to do with the amazing music present in the game. If you're playing for the first time, you'll likely finish the story in 2-3 hours with maybe 600 or so deaths.       Fortunately, completing the story is only part of the fun. If you're going for 100%, you'll also have a chance to experience the joy of going back through the game and hunting down all 20 Trinkets (I'm sure you'll love the Veni Vidi Vici Trinket) the insane speed trials (Where you have to complete levels in the game within a pre-determined time frame), the more-than fun Super Gravitron (Your goal is to survive 1 full minute during which all you can do is move left and right to avoid a never-ending onslaught of obstacles coming from both sides. My personal best for that is a bit above 20 seconds), and of course, trying to get the hardest achievement in the game, which is......No Death ModeAs the name implies, you have to beat the entire game with only 1 life. Screw up even once, and you're back at the start. You're guaranteed to have fun dodging broken hearts, surviving the Gravitron for 60 seconds straight, avoiding spikes, and clinging on to dear life in the Dial M For Murder room.    If you find that mode too easy, you can always do an all-trinket no death run, I guess.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												This is a very fun platformer, but I can only recommend it on a condition: if bright lights and strobes do not affect you. Some of the levels are intense, and I found myself sort of spacing out and getting lost in the bright colorful lights. I can't imagine what this would do to someone with epilepsy, but it would definitely be very bad. As it is, I had to turn it off after playing the same level for about five minutes and not being able to make the jump because it was changing between screens so rapidly and the colors were so bright that I couldn't take it. And I'm not epileptic, I've never had this kind of problem with a game before. So yes, I recommend it, in short doses to people who aren't bothered by strobes of light and color. But I can't imagine myself playing this for an hour or two straight, it's really more of a "take five minutes to enjoy the soundtrack" kind of game.--------------------------------------------------------------------If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page? Click here to do that thing!

												Not to be confused with ΛΛΛΛΛΛ (a future terrible Chinese knock-off that attempts to fool people into thinking it's the real thing [sound familiar?]), this is not a game more than it is a simulation of the events that would occur if you just happened to be in a pixelated space-ship with 6 other people in the near future. This non-casual title will put your flipping abilities, and propaganda filtering to the test as you explore and rescue the rest of your missing team in seemingly endless, and whimsically named rooms for each of the levels.This is a title you must try.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game is unique. It has a great soundtrack. It's challenging. There's really no reason not to buy it. For a game that I thought was just a funny jumping game, it really got me invested in the storyline, which although is short, is fun and makes sense, something that I feel a lot of games don't do. I love it.My only three cons are not even about the gameplay, which I feel is incredible.1. The game is short, it only took me about 2 hours to beat it, but it has a lot of replay value, as most of the achievements/alternate modes are unlockable/achievable after beating the game.2. If you are epileptic, you shouldn't buy this. I won't say when, but the game at some point has a lot of flashing colors.3. If you rage easily (no offense) then you probably shouldn't  buy this either. You will die A LOT on your first run.tl;dr 10/10 I very much recommend this game to anyone looking for a very unique and challenging game.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2011
												All this game has going for it is its retro style, especially the music which I really enjoyed.The gameplay though is frustrating and tedious.  You die over and over as you try and precisely time your key-presses to navigate a tricky section full of spikes or other nasties.  There're always savepoints before the difficult sections and respawning is very fast but these are not enough to remove the frustration.The story is poorly written but you probably wouldn't play a game like this for the story anyway.VVVVVV is worth trying out if you're into difficult platformers.  Otherwise it's not worth your time.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2011
												Innovative little platformer. The graphics are extremely simple though, very basic. In this game you have to find your friends. There are a lot of spiked platforms and you can avoid them by pressing a button to switch the gravity. So instead of walking, you'll then fall down and you're able to avoid them. It sounds easier than it actually is. It can be quite difficult. So if you're into hard platformers add this one to your list. The price is very good.[Rating: 77/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												VVVVVV is a challenging yet short indie platformer that is well worth the cost and a lovely fun time as a whole. The game's main innovative platforming mechanic of doing away with jumps and instead allowing the player to flip gravity in the opposite direction is delightfully fun and memorable. The characters in the game are likable even without a gripping, dramatic story and long dialogues, and the environment is easy to understand and fun to explore. Overall, the game has an atmosphere that's hard to describe perfectly, I feel. This game's only noticable short-coming, if I had to give it one, is its length; it's not too terribly long, giving the average player somewhere in the ballpark of six to twelve hours of gameplay. However short this game is, though, I absolutely recommend it. Great things come in small packages, eh? Terry Cavanagh did an excellent job as a lone developer.Special attention must be paid to this game's music, composed by Magnus Pålsson. This game is worth the price you pay just for the game's soundtrack alone. I'm a video game music aficionado, and this game has one of my favorite soundtracks amongst all games I've ever played. Please, do yourself a favor and either play this game or find and listen to the soundtrack by itself. Add this amazing music to a wonderful, impressionable game? Just, damn... it's too good. It's truly incredible.

Но игра в своем жанре на высоте. Красивое оформление, приятная 8-битная музыка и графика, интресные мисии и много другое. Конечно может комуто цена не понравится, то ждите скидку. А так моя оценка 5+ :D

number of helpful: 58 of 117 people (50%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												OK, a serious review this time - maybe this game simply wasn't *for* me. I've never really been a fan of retro-styled platformers, probably because I didn't grow up with them so the nostalgia doesn't really do anything for me. I've tried to play some of the classics but the ones that do hold up (Mega Man, Gimmick!) still have plenty of gameplay flaws that their indie counterparts don't seem to want to let go of.VVVVVV has a great, great soundtrack (I even bought it) but it's an immensely frustating game in a way that it's arcade contemporary Super Meat Boy is not. You respawn instantly, like that game, but with an irritating sound effect that feels like a punishment for dying. The odd control scheme is slippery and feels inconsistent, although I'll admit some people have mastered it enough to speedrun it. And, unlike many of Super Meat Boy's levels where you see what is coming far before tackling it, VVVVVV by design blindsides you with its Zelda-style screen scrolls into traps you have no time to prepare for. Veni Vidi Vici is the quintessential example of this design philosophy in action.What this results in is a game that is entirely based on trial-and-error. That's really all it has - the actual platforming isn't fun due to the slow pace and iffy controls, so what it does instead is throw a bunch of gimmicks at you while you slowly inch your way through an Atari-skinned meat grinder. There's some elements of exploration in the hub world (one of the songs is even called Passion For Exploring) but nothing to really do in it, making it just a fancy version of a level select.This could all be fine if the game was charming or interesting enough to make up for these flaws (Gimmick! is also a frustrating game with a lot of trial-and-error) but, unfortunately, it really isn't. The characters are literally stick figures. The world is mostly blocks and spikes with an occasionally cute theme or object in a room, reinforced by the nice touch of giving every room its own name, but its very barebones.Obviously, many people have enjoyed VVVVVV a lot, and saying something binary like "this game is the worst thing ever" is silly and unfair. But my honest opinion is that it's just not worth the short time you put into it.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												That may seem hyperbolic, but the attention to detail put into this game really shows. I've always like retro videogame soundtracks, but Palsson's chiptune work is sublime here. The game is short, and the plot is sparse, but IMO it's exactly as long and detailed as it needs to be to accomplish what it's trying to here. It distills the essence of platformers down to an hour or three of madcap wall-bouncing with no apologies.Segments of this game can be brutally hard, but never feel unfair. You can dive face first into the same set of spikes 5 times in a row, for the same reasons, but still feel like you're learning how to dodge it better on the 6th try. You're EXPECTED to dive face first into spikes... over and over... which is why there are checkpoints in basically every room (sometimes several in the SAME room!) to give you almost zero delay on death, like all the best torture-platformers. If you want to collect all of the Shiny Trinkets, there are some real gems of happy frustration to be found (one with an actual note laughing at those with the guts to try it). If you want a smooth, easy ride, or if your manual dexterity isn't what it used to be, then you may get overly frustrated here, but if not...Overall, if you like platformers, and you like chiptune music, and you like supporting indie games, why don't you have this yet?

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Easily one of the best platforms ive played in a long while. The game is great. The levels are challenging, and sometimes appear daunting, but with a little practice (or luck) they can be overcome with great satisfaction. Souleye did a wonderous job on the retro style music for this, and the sounds harken back to the old-school days of 8-bit platformers. While it is on the short side, the difficulty of the game and its unlockable gamemodes and challenges keep it fun for much longer. Its open-world style map can be a bit confusing, and you may find yourself in an area much more challenging than what you are ready for, but if you do find yourself in a situation like that, you can leave the area and try somewhere else. If you havn't given this game a try, I seriously reccomend playing the free demo and getting the game. VVVVVV is a great platformer with great gameplay, a great soundtack, and enough challenge to keep you playing for hours, and its low price makes it even better.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Easily one of the best platforms ive played in a long while. The game is great. The levels are challenging, and sometimes appear daunting, but with a little practice (or luck) they can be overcome with great satisfaction. Souleye did a wonderous job on the retro style music for this, and the sounds harken back to the old-school days of 8-bit platformers. While it is on the short side, the difficulty of the game and its unlockable gamemodes and challenges keep it fun for much longer. Its open-world style map can be a bit confusing, and you may find yourself in an area much more challenging than what you are ready for, but if you do find yourself in a situation like that, you can leave the area and try somewhere else. If you havn't given this game a try, I seriously reccomend playing the free demo and getting the game. VVVVVV is a great platformer with great gameplay, a great soundtack, and enough challenge to keep you playing for hours, and its low price makes it even better.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												An indubiably difficult and challenging platformer with a twist! So relentlessly frustrating, it is one of those games that I want to meet the designer (to punch him in the face! :) ). The world is eerie and sublime harkening back to 8-bit brilliance but has a wonderful marriage of gameplay and an excellent sci-fi story justifying everything. And the music goes right along with the eerie 8bit sci-fi vibe. SOOOOOO Satisying that I beat it...So satisfying...but egad those trinkets! we hates the trinketsses forever!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												There's not much more to say about this game: it's a work of genius and a must for every old school gamer raised with bread and C64. The amazing part is that the entire game could have been done on a real c64 (a part from the music, the color palette and obviously disk only). It's a game from the future that could have been done exactly as it is in the past. I like to imagine the reaction of the gaming community back in the eighties if presented with a game like this...it blows my mind!

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												This is a minimalist game with great platforming and music. In most platforming games you have the ability to jump whereas in this game whenever you press up you flip, turning the ceiling into the floor and the floor into the ceiling. The level design is very clever and you are left with a great sense of accomplishment when you get past a particularly difficult part. Even after completion this game kept me coming back to see if I could improve my high score in the Super Gravitron. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												VVVVVV takes its name from the game's main objective, which I shall not touch upon in order to leave the discovery to you. The first aspect of the game that took me by surprise is the superb 8-bit chiptune music. The only problem with that is that it does get repetitive only because it replays one single track for about 30 minutes at a time, until you complete each level. The graphics are imitating the general style of the Commodore 64, including its startup screen. VVVVVV's main platforming mechanic is the player's ability to flip the character's screen position vertically, going from bottom to top and vice versa. This makes for some complicated platforming in general, as well as some challenging and entertaining rooms. Because of the game's incredible difficulty, the developers have cleverly implemented checkpoints liberally throughout the game world, which cuts down on rage and frustration. With that said, VVVVVV still manages to be extremely difficult, and you should expect to die hundreds of times, if not one thousand times by the time you complete the game. The platforming and controls are not badly designed, as in Super Meat Boy, so do not confuse this well crafted, yet simplistic game with that developmental disaster. Younger generations of gamers may find the overall presentation of VVVVVV to be unique and hip, but as we all know, these graphics have been done before, about 30 years ago. One serious flaw is that there are no audio options for volume. The in-game default is quite higher than usual, and requires turning down in Windows. While the majority of the levels' rooms are a lot of fun, and well designed, some are simply unreasonable and require too much luck as opposed to actual precision and skill. Because of this, you will die many times and spend far too long attempting single rooms. Which also means being forced to listen to a single song on a loop, for the entire duration of your trials. This is something of a shortcoming and should have been avoided completely by the developers, as these uncalled-for rooms only add negatively to the experience. Even though you get unlimited lives and unlimited continues, having to repeat a single room hundreds of times in order to pass it gets boring, repetitive, annoying, and only serves the purpose of replacing actual content with limited and mundane game play. While the music is once again, excellent, there are only a few that repeat over and over, as the rest must be unlocked by finding and collecting certain orbs within the game world. There are also a few more game modes for the player to experiment with once the campaign has been completed. The storyline and ending are endearing and delightful, and once you complete the game, there is an overall feeling of satisfaction. VVVVVV is short but perfectly sweet.VVVVVV is good.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												VVVVVV is a simple platformer released in 2010 which simplifies it's basics into one rule: what if you reverse gravity instead of jumping? This is an interesting rule used in this game and it impacts on how you play the game, too. No skill is required to play this game; you can simply pick up the game and discover things as you go through.So, VVVVVV is about Captain Viridian and his crew in space on the D.S.S Souleye, which then the flight to an unknown area has been interrupted, and the crew has to evacuate, however the evacuation goes wrong and Viridian is left on his own requiring him to save his crew members in Dimension VVVVVV. The plot seems interesting, however the only thing concerned is that the characters never mention the year, assuming it is in the future due to the teleport technology used. They do not also mention age, and gender, although colors and personality shape the genders of the characters.The difficulty of the game is similar to Super Meat Boy: the difficulty is simple on the first stages like the introduction level and onward from the Lab, it gets challenging.Overall, this game is good except the fact that if you don't like difficulty, please leave.I'd rate this game a 9/10. This game also has good music. BUY THE SOUNDTRACK!

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												VVVVVV is a platformer at heart, but is it a platformer you will want to play ? You play as Captain Viridian whose spaceship gets caught in a space warp. The warp damages the ship and scatters the crew of the ship in space so its up to you to find them and rescue them. So how is this game ? Its a great platformer without a doubt. Youre Charecter controlls great and if you die its pretty much youre fault. The game style is sort of like those Metroidvania games. It has an open world enviroment and you can go where you want. Even though it might seem simple enough this game gets very complex on the later parts of the game. Youre charecter can choose where to walk on the ceilling or on the floor. Later levels get really hard and it might make you quit the game, but the game never gets so difficult that you will never finish it. The music is really awesome and its one of the best soundtracks out there. The only major flaw is that this game is pretty short almost under 2 hours. Overall a really good game that if by the time youre reading this review havent played it, check it out right now great music, awesome enviroments and collectibels throught the game you can find to increase the games lenght. I give VVVVVV a 8/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												This game is awesome from a retro-gamming perspective.  The gravity reversal mechanics add something to the game play  that makes it really fun to play despite the simplistic graphics.  I feel like I'm playing berzerk but on a better platform with a twist.  The game is hard and rewarding.  You feel achievement when completing a checkpoint.  When you make a mistake, it is usually because you forgot to orient yourself to the reversed mechanic in order to get past a set of obstacles.  It's addicting and challenges the mind.   I saw Mike Matei live stream this game a couple days ago.  It was so interesting to watch, I had to give it try.EDIT:One bad thing I noticed is that the character walking is slippery and inconsistent.  Sometimes a slight press in a direction bursts him into a full run often hitting spikes.  Other times his movements barely register leading to death in some other way.  Sometimes the character has momentum, and sometimes he does not.  I never understood why game devs release games like that, but overall the rest of the game is stable.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												This game is one of those faux hard games where it is generally the fact that you can't see what is coming in the next room that kills you, not interesting AI or challenging puzzles. I persoanlly do not appreciate these types of games, but I do understand there is an audience for them. If you are into speed runs and that sort of thing, then this might be for you. I do not beleive this applies to most people though.The actual exploration of the world was really cool though, I always love Metroid style exploration. I beleive that it was done well, with the map being quite interesting, and each section having some really unique bits and pieces to seperate it from other parts of the world.The last thing worth mentioing is that it is incrediby short if you are just trying to finish the "main story". I'm not the best at these games, but the 1.8 hours is all it took. No doubt the time trials will make up for this for people willing to go through some severe frustration.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												This game has a great concept, challenging puzzles and levels, and a cute storyline, but is let down by the slippery controls. People have complained about this issue, but the dev refuses to fix the inertia saying that "it's important to the feel of the game". I guess it's OK for the casual player, but when there's an achievement for completing the game deathless, and I'm the kind of guy who will aim for this achievement, the inertia makes what should be a fun challenge into rage-quit difficulty. 6/10, not recommended for 100% completionists like myself.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												TL:DR I don't recommend this game unless you like punishingly hard platforming and don't my sloppy controls.This interesting game that started out as intriguing and engaging quickly turned into an exercise of frustration and anger. Dexterity challenges and puzzles became mean spirited and unenjoyably difficult. I found myself cursing the game on many occasion "♥♥♥♥♥♥this game!" I only finished it because I knew that my friend had and that it is mercifully short. Overall I'm pretty disappointed in the overall experience of this game and wouldn't recommend it. The Good:Open world to explore. I really dug this aspect of the game. Even though it is a fairly small world it makes the whole game feel more cohesive.Some really great mechanics and level design. Fun challengesThe Bad:Shoddy controls. Half the time I died was because the character wouldn't stop when I wanted or go as far as I needed it to when commanded.Lame graphics. The 4 bit art style itself was not offensive to me. I thought it kinda charming. It was the "enemies", obstacles, and "glitchy" elements of the game that just were just plain lame or ugly.The music, which was pretty catchy at first, overtime became annoying due to how much it repeats as you replay a section over and over again.The Ugly:Level design that just feels mean. I seriously felt like the designers were laughing at me as I struggled to overcome some of the ridiculous sections of the game. The frequency of some of the check points are an indicator of just how difficult some parts of the game are.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												VVVVVV is a 2D platformer that revolves around gathering all the crew members after an emergency in their spacecraft.PROS:+ Very challenging+ Simple but unique gameplay+ Takes very little space and performance+ Nice music+ Fair priceCONS: - Can get very frustrating only in a short time- Which leads to the second point that whilst playing this game you don't feel any urge to beat a level or continue playing it. It's not satisfying- Not so very well-timed save stations- Most of the stages are quite similar in terms of hazards (99.9% of the enemies are spikes)- Gets repetitive really fastOveral, it's hard to keep playing this game not against your will, as it can deliver the opposite desired effect of gaming: frustration. Wishing you'd rather play something else is never a good sign. The game isn't the worst, but it could have been better.My rating: 5/10

Posted: March 25, 2016
												Really obnoxious gameplay.The problem solving could be fun, but the way that the screen constantly and suddenly changes makes some traps impossible to dodge the first time and/or artificially harder for no good reason, and it's irritating having to shift my sight up and down, left and right so often; it's a game that actually harms me physically.  This gameplay mechanic is not a good idea, but I'd give it credit for trying this oddity...It doesn't help as well that the controls are either unbearably stiff or oddly sensitive.Its one saving grace would be that, while not easy at times, it can be beaten quickly enough, so my eyes didn't had time to bleed.

												VVVVV is simple yet great indie game that will test your skills (and nerves). Awesome 8bit fast paced music will keep you going even if you fail 1000 times. Overall - must have!WHY SHOULD YOU PLAY:- fast paced gameplay and smooth controls - really well paced music fitting the game- traps which will test your skills where you will achieve great satisfication when overcoming them- replay value (collectables...)- good example that even oldschool graphics can still make an amazing gameTHINGS YOU MAY NOT LIKE:- it's hard, you will die a lot so you will need a lot of nerves - graphics may turn off some people

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												*I RECOMMEND GETTING IT WHEN ON SALE - I BOUGHT IT FOR ABOUT A BUCK WHICH IS WORTH IT*          VVVVVV is a retro style platformer with a great Atari art scheme and very Mega Man-esque music and sound effects. The presentation of the game is on point, but I often felt the gameplay fell short in some aspects.     The game is esentially a platformer, with a gravity switch mechanic as opposed to a regular jump. You will be using your ability to jump to the ceiling (or to the floor) in order to traverse the world and many levels of the game. This transition from hub world to levels is fun and seemless, allowing you to get a grip of the game mechanics early, but soon you will be throwing that out the window.     Levels will consist very rarely oF your ability to time a gravity switch on the fly. Instead, as the game uses a board to board style, you will be doing plenty of 'leaps of faith' into traps you have little chance of seeing or reacting to. Levels are designed in such a way that force you to use trial and error, which gives a false sense of difficulty.     Aside from leaps of faith, the game has a frustrating amount of timing sequences that rarely use the gravity switch feature. Your ability to dodge things left and right will be tested often, which isn't helped by the imprecise movement in the game. Even if the game controlled better, I felt as though I wasn't using the gravity swap enough in these situations. This is the equivalent of playing Portal, and solving puzzles with your aiming skills alone. If you aren't using the core mechanic of the game, I begin to wonder why it's even there.     VVVVVV prides itself on it's difficulty, which seems like salt in the wound when the game gets unfairly difficult. Levels/boards will have cheeky names and some of the acheivements ask for minimal amounts of deaths. I probably spent about an hour attempting to get the 'Doing things the hard way' Trinket which is the worst of all the 'trail and error/leap of faith' sections in the game. Asthetics alone can't really hold this game afloat despite my love for them. On sale this game is interesting and probably worth the money, but for $5, it's too frustrating and just not unique enough by most indie game standards.

												As this is not a review, just a recomendation(even though that's what steam is calling it, it isn't. The only option it has for a 'score' is a yes or no), I will say why I do not recomend this game. It's too hard. Thats it. No broken game mechanics, no bugs, just hard. If you are like me and get frusterated when you lose a lot, or dont find the satisfaction of winning worth losing (especially on this level) then don't get this game. If you like to speed run things and/or games like Mega Man, Super Hexagon, or Sonic the Hedgehog, and have a lot of pacience, get this game, but only if that is the only mechanic that you love about them. This game has one mechanic, which is switching gravity. No guns, no 'real' enemies (there are things shaped like enemies, but those are really only just fancy walls), no nothing. Barebones. It's not a bad game, and is honest about what it is. But if that isn't appealing, then don't get this game.
