content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												I bought this game on recommendation from a friend, and a vague memory of playing it before. Was it in flash-game format once upon a time? The music is glorious retro, and the loading screen will send you back to the days of the Spectrum ZX. Graphics are inevitably classic retro, the screenshots say it all.The gameplay, due to controls and level design, is very unpleasant for me. The concept is decent, with an interesting mechanic where you flip your own gravity to overcome obstacles, but the puzzle-platformer I was expecting is nowhere to be seen. It's an arcade-platformer through and through and if that's not what you're after then it's not the game for you. The left/right controls have a little acceleration, so movement where you need precision is sloppy and largely guesswork. If you play long enough you'll probably get it, but that's not the point - the controls should work for you, you shouldn't need to work around the controls.Level design is at times cruel and unfair, with a forced-speedrun section courtesy of a rising floor, and various traps that are only found through trial and error. For example, want to know what's in the screen to the left? There's a bump, so you need to jump, but you can't do that so you have to invert gravity, and there's no ceiling. Hope there aren't spikes in any of the 3-4 screens you have to fall through. Of course there are spikes. There are spikes in so many places (as there should be!) that it really makes the game mechanics work against you. There are the usual timing sections, but there certainly isn't a lot of leeway. You'll be dying a lot. And there's a slight delay on the respawn. Just long enough to wind you up as you retry a section (particularly the forced speedrun) over and over again.Lastly, the game mocks you. All the screens are individually named, and the developer has taken the time to use them to mock you. Not the endearing mockery as found in Portal, no, this will feel like genuine malice that in combination with the levels they refer to will give a good idea of the contempt the developer has for the player.I truly regret paying what little money I did for this game, as it has brought nothing but frustration. Incidentally if you want a game that hates you (and not in a good way, like Darkest Dungeon), this game is for you. No, my money would've been better spent donated to the developers of the (free) SHIFT.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												VVVVVV is a very simple platformer that runs with one simple idea. You can change gravity instead of jumping. Right into the review.This game is filled with frustrating design concepts that force you to replay the same situation over and over. Not to mention the sometimes-overly sensitive-sometimes not movement. One pixel hitting a spike? Dead. Pressed on the arrow key for a fraction of a second too long? You will go flying off the platform right into death. Most of the situations in the game aren't actually that hard. But they are just set up in such a way that you will fail over and over until you finally get lucky enough and you can fall down a pit pixel by exact pixel not hitting any spikes on the way down. It would be like trying to drop a quarter into a slot machine from 10 feet up. Its not challenging, just repititive and tedious. Its not enjoyable, its frustrating. This game is not imaginative. The concepts and level designs have all been done before. This game isn't revolutionary, its not Braid, and it is certaintly no Fez. The concept of changing gravity to move around the world has a lot of potential. But the designer was either a lazy designer or a bad puzzle maker. Instead of making a thoughtful puzzle game that requires much head scratching and brain storming. They went for a cheap "avoid the red spikes" route. The levels are all mapped out, sure there is an over world. But its laughable compared to what gamers in this day and age are used to. Avoid the spikes, run to the end, rescue the person. Boring.Now most of that I could live with. Its unimaginative sure, but at least it wasn't too frustrating. But the one thing that did it for me, the one thing that just killed the game for me, was the escort mission. Yeah you heard me, there is an escort mission. I can just imagine the developer sitting around thinking to himself. "You know what this platformer needs? An escort mission. I bet the player would enjoy that." Its completely surreal that anyone would even put an escort mission into a platformer. The NPC that you are escorting follows you from a couple feet behind you. So now, not only do you have to make it through the extremely accurate maze riddled with spikes, but you also have to guide this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ NPC through it as well. It got frustrating, fast.So, even though I love platformers and really wanted to like this game. I can't, I just can't. Don't get me wrong, its fun, for awhile. But then all the bad design choices just leap out at you as you play through the game. Honestly the quality of this game is something I would expect in a common flash game that I played online when I was in middle school. Now if I had recieved the game in that setting, I would have loved it. But that fact that someone is asking money for a game of this quality astounds me.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This game is overrated. The fact that VVVVVV perfectly recreates the arcades of 1980s or challenges the timing skills of players in the fashion similar to “Super Meat Boy” does not oblige anyone to burst into nostalgic tears and rate the game as an indisputable masterpiece. It is not for the lack of atmosphere that I do not recommend the game — old arcades often had an “excuse plot” and that was perfectly fine. It is not the difficulty — these games have nurtured generations of hardcore players that achieved robotic precision mastering the levels (compare “Mega Man”). The overall scale seems too small, the world is not detailed and diverse enough: even within that abstract and geometric style one could have created stupendous mazes with specific traits and unique atmosphere. Could have, but has not. Some suspicion that this game was hyped just because “indie developers must be supported” still lurks in my mind.Creating a game “à la eighties” to honour the timeless 8-bit æsthetics is such a responsible task, and one cannot just take the mechanics and the look of a different epoch and reproduce them using modern approach. Compare Jamestown — a perfect old-school shoot-'em-up game that is really indistinguishable from the 1990s shooters. It is so easy to trick anyone into thinking that it had been created 20 years ago because the look and feel are very convincing. On the contrary, you can’t plausibly think of “VVVVVV” as an 1980s game. With an aching heart I do post this review, without any hope to gain recognition or ingratiate myself with fans’ favour.

number of helpful: 20 of 54 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												This is a painful platformer that is really simple to play. You can move left and right, but instead of jumping you reverse your own gravity. So instead of having your feet pointed toward the bottom, you push the space bar to have your feet pointed to the top and you float to the top. Its a great mechanic.The game consists of a small open world that lets you go anywhere you'd like all to rescue your crew members. The screen doesn't scroll. When you touch a side of the screen, it brings you to the next screen like Zelda. The game mostly feels like challenge rooms, dodging spikes. Hence the name VVVVVV. There are checkpoints everywhere, so when you get spiked, you'll always go back to the last checkpoint. Later in the game it makes use of the single screen mechanic where if you exit the left, you'll appear on the right side of the same screen. It is a distraction and several 'challenges' span more than one screen. The trippy moving backgrounds don't help either.The music is happy 8-Bit chip tunes. The simple art style is good, its just not that fun to play. There isn't just precision platforming, but diving down pits and precision platforming, shifting your character in mid air to avoid spikes.It can all be completed in 90 minutes or less. The game has a few extra modes like time trials and flip where the world is flipped. Its all extra challenge.If you're the type to enjoy a steep challenge where your only reward is more challenge, then this is the game for you. It has also been in a few bundles for a cheap price, so I'd recommend waiting for a bundle.

number of helpful: 45 of 110 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Nice retro music and graphics, if that's your thing. But that's about all this game has going for itself. As for the difficulty, there is hard, then there is unfair. This game leans heavily toward the unfair side. "Hard" can be something like Super Meat Boy where you can plainly see all the challenges in front of you, and it's up to you to be skillful enough to pass them. VVVVVV's version of challenge is to punish players for not being psychic. It's trial-and-error gameplay at its worst. Your vision is limited to 1 tiny screen at a time. Get to the edge of the screen, and you appear in the next one. If you happen to be falling (up OR down, in this game) you go very fast and if there just happens to be a pit of spikes in your path, you die and there is little you can do other than remember they are there during your next attempt.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Ever play Dark Souls? Remember how one wrong move could get you killed? This is Dark Souls as a platformer. That's not good. In fact, that's bad. Imagine Super Meat Boy without the tight controls. Imagine that one game that's really easy to compare every other game to. This game possesses some traits from that game, but not good ones.Also, a notable lack of replay value, given the fact that it's the same game when you play it again and there's no way to change the play. Every stage must be completed in the same way, no matter how many times you do it. Oh, there are parts where you have a "choice." That means you can go over or under the object in your way.It gets worse when you're trying to lead your comrades out of the hole they've gotten themselves in, because they, in the immense knowledge of the programmers, only move given certain criteria that you aren't told and have to discover through trial and error.All in all, it's a good game if you hate yourself and/or are interested in contemplating suicide.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2010
												This is an interesting platformer with a simple concept: you cannot jump, but you can change your gravity alignment.First of all: I can not recommend this game.The graphics style is comforting and the music is great, but the gameplay and game itself is quite annoying. It took me about 2 hours and I were extremely happy that I finished it, but not because it was good, but because it was too annoying. The jumps you had to do were overall just too unfair at most times to be fun, the controls were just slightly too unresponsive to be fun to use in tight quarters. At one part, having to control an NPC by proximity was by far the most annoying thing I've had to do in a game this year. Dying around 200 times were about as much as I could take, where in contrast I've probably died around 3000 times in Super Meat Boy.If you want to play another platformer where the controls are tighter, music is good and you die a lot, I'd recommend Super Meat Boy.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												I'm going to say this straight up.  You need to have a lot of patience if you want to have any hope of beating this game.  This game is *hard.*Now that that's out of the way, on to the review.  The game, VVVVVV, is a hardcore platformer designed around the manipulation of gravity.  The controls are very simple:  left, right, and change the gravitational pull.  However, do not be fooled by its apparent simplicity.  This game, from beginning to end, is meant to challenge and frustrate, and only the most patient and skilled of players will be able to succeed.  There are various different "levels" connected by a hub world, with each level presenting a different mechanic, such as wires that instantly switch gravity to auto-scrolling levels, for the player to learn.  While the beginnings of these levels are meant to ease the player in, by the end of each section, the player will be required to have mastered the mechanic, if he or she wishes to succeed and move on.  This all culminates in a final level designed to test even the best of players.While a story is present, it's mainly just filler between levels, like many platformers.  However, in a game like this, I find one unnecessary, as that's not what the game is ultimately about.  I would even argue that too much story is present at times, as it can be a bit irritating to be forced to scroll through conversations to get to the next area.Finally, I must say that I love its music, a fast-paced ode to the older days of the NES and SNES.  It really fits the tone of the game and gets you pumped and ready for the challenges to come.Overall, this is a great game, and I fully recommend it to any who want to truly test their platforming skills.  This receives, from me, a 9/10.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game is challenging but very fair. The mechanic of you flipping every time you jump is fantastic, and each level is meticulously designed with this mechanic in mind. My favorite levels are probably the "endless scrolling" type levels [think pacman or the first mario brothers (pre-SMB1) where you exit the screen at the left and enter at the right]. Really makes for some neat platforming that causes you to think a little bit diferently.   The timing can be quite tight at times, so this would probably be a good game for speed runners as it just feels great to really try and fly through the levels. There is a time attack mode for those who want to try and learn how to speed run the game.   The graphics are minimal but do the job, either way you're not playing this to be blown away by visuals anyway, as the game play is smart and addictive. The soundtrack is also littered with fantastic chip tune music.   If you want a platfromer with a well implemented gimmick, you should definitely pick this up. You won't regret it at any price point this game generally sells for.

												This indie game is at the forefront of its genre, with its catchy music and interesting gameplay. The story is pretty good- you have to rescue your lost crewmates after a system meltdown on your ship. The best feature of this game would have to be the creative way of moving around. Along with walking left and right, you can also flip gravity to move onto the ceiling, opening up brand new level designs. The music in this game is something to be praised. Keeping up with its source material's title, the soundtrack is called "PPPPPP" since all of the tracks start with the letter, you guessed it, "P." Posted: June 20, 2014
												9/10This game is a fun return to classic action-platformers, where mental and physical reflexes make all the difference. The graphics are colorful without being headache-inducing, and the main mechanic of the game is simple to use but difficult to master. The backstory is engaging, and uncovered one piece at a time. The puzzles run the gamot from simple to brain-bending. Expect to die a lot on your first playthrough. Rooms that took you one try in one direction can take you fifteen tries going the other direction. My only complaint is that the story is relatively short, but this is assuaged by the multiple modes of play. Definitely something to play over and over!

												Though you'll be punished a lot… though you'll be frustrated at times… though you will find yourself quitting occasionally.. you will be forgiving. You’ll immediately be thrown into the core gameplay without having to go through endless numbers of boring tutorials. For once also a game I found challenging instead of something you just "walk over". Some areas might seem impossible at first, but once your mind starts to grasp the gravity flipping mechanic you’ll be set on collecting all the trinkets. Checkpoints in each area make sure that you never feel you really loosing any progress.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												This is a pretty amazing game. It features but three buttons, really: Left, Right, and Flip. Left and Right do what they say, and "flip" inverts gravity.From there, it extrapolates an nice story (which indeed feels like it isn't a last-ditch plot to get you places), and very challenging gameplay. It isn't very large (once you do everything, there isn't a ton of replay value or anything), but it's big enough to satisfy, especially for the 40 cents I paid (thank you sale). Wouldn't have gotten it if that sale didn't happen, and I'm happy to have played it.The one point against it is this is the type of game where you die. A lot. Even after finishing the story (still got two coins to collect, but those two might be difficult), I died multiple times in the starting rooms. This game has spikes, and lots of them. So, if you're going to enjoy this game, you'll have to not get bogged down by deaths. But besides that, it's a good game. I enjoyed. Wait for a sale if you wish, but playing this game is a good experience.

												This is a small, but fun game made from geometric shapes. The sotry is that you are on a spaceship with a crew, and you get stuck in a parallel dimension, and your crew gets randomly teleported to different parts of the map. As the captain, you have to find your crew and get out and back to your own dimension. The main power that you have with which to navigate is the ability to basically change the direction of the force of gravity on your character, up and down. It can get challenging at times, but well worth playing.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game is amazing!  I admit that I'm a sucker for retro-style games, but this one does it well.  It focuses on having an incredible game mechanic idea and uses it to its fullest extent.  Then it has bright graphics that really help fit the mood, despite its intended limitations, and the soundtrack is pure chip-tune awesomeness.  In fact, i would go so far as to say that the music made going through the game much more pleasantly.  This game is hard, but it's a kind of fair-hard that gives you tons of checkpoints, and the music only pushes you forward through the game.  Even when I was struggling with the infmaous Veni Vidi Vici, the soundtrack was so upbeat that I simply kept trying and trying until i got it.There is no reason to not at least try the demo, and if you play the demo more than twice, you have no excuse to not buy this game.  It's only $5, and that's when it's not on sale!  HIGHLY recommended.

Posted: May 10, 2014
												No school like the old school, or so they say. VVVVVV is a very simple 2D platformer with the caveat that, instead of jumping, you have the ability to reverse gravity. While this may sound trivial, playing through just a few rooms will tell you all you need to know: this game intends to be hard. Thankfully, there are a ton of builtin "save states" scattered all over, but nevertheless, be prepared for some frustration - and hopefully some fun too!It is a very short game, but there is an undeniable charm to it, and the graphics and audio are very well done for the style of game VVVVVV is. If you ever find yourself wanting a challenge and some nostalgia for older days of gaming, I would recommend giving this one a try.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												Ah VVVVVV.  What can be said about this indie hit that hasn’t already been said?  Well, I could say its a hamster served with gravy, a side of steak fries, and an ice cold cola.  Of course that would be a lie, but it probably hasn’t been said before.This game is centered around one simple concept: You can't jump.  Instead you reverse gravity to get from point A to point B.  The goal is to find your five crew members and get them all, along with yourself, back to the ship.  While it lets you tackle some of the puzzles in the order you want, in-between it throws required puzzles at you.  And let me tell you, those puzzles are hard.  And by those puzzles I mean all of them.The game has pretty tight controls, a good thing because many of the games puzzles rely on pulling off tight maneuvers mid-air and landing on relatively small platforms.  That being said, sometimes I did find myself slipping off of various platforms or that I continue moving when I wanted to stop.  This may have been my accidental holding of the button, or may have been momentum actually being slightly carried, I’m not sure.  The music is good, and defiantly fits into the game.  Though it is weird how sometimes it fades out, as if to start the loop again, then picks right back up and keeps going.This is also a relatively short game and it's minimalistic on the graphics.  This brings me to my biggest complaint about the game: It felt like a Flash game.  In a world with free games available on sites such as Kongregate and Armor Games, it's hard to make an argument for buying a game when it looks like it could be played in a web browser.   Of course, the line between Flash, Mobile, and low end PC games is beginning to blur.However, this game is defiantly worth the money.  At around $5 the game delivers, and despite feeling minimalist and Flash game-y, doesn’t make you feel like you got ripped off.Overall, I give it a 9/10.  I have to dock a point for the loss of my sanity somewhere in the dimensions of the game.  Really, this game will steal your sanity.  I mean, I opened this review talking about serving hamster.  Regardless, this game is worth playing.Oh yea, and it's especially definitely worth it when you can get it for less than $0.50 and the money all came from selling trading cards on the Steam marketplace.  Don't you LOVE Steam sales, I know I do!

Posted: July 15, 2012
												Even though I've beaten this game I just can't bring myself to uninstall it. It's too awesome.VVVVVV is a puzzle platformer based on gravity reversal. Rather than treat this as a gimmick tacked onto an ordinary platform game, VVVVVV weaves this mechanic into every part of the game. About the only thing you can do other than walk left and right is reverse gravity, and you'll do this about a dozen times per screen, more depending on how often you die.Speaking of which, you'll die. Hundreds of times. Spikes adorn practically every surface in this game. Checkpoints are abundant and when you die you're back in the game immediately, so this isn't nearly as frustrating as it sounds.Speaking of sounds, the sounds and graphics in this game are a twell-executed throwback to the Commodore 64 era, and the chiptune-style soundtrack is as as catchy as anything on the NES. (I've been listening to "Potential for Anything" nearly every day for weeks now.)You want this game!

Posted: July 6, 2011
												I love this game. It has a nice twist where instead of jumping, your character's direction of gravity is flipped, which makes for great puzzles. The music is really good too. The game is styled to look like a Commodore 64 game, which is nice. I wouldn't recomend playing the game in fullscreen, though, as the game looks blurry then. Maximizing the window doesn't look blurry, though.UPDATE 9/7/11: Thanks to the game's new 2.0 update that rewrites everything from Flash to C++, the game can be played in fullscreen without looking blurry. However, you can no longer maximize th window, and you can only choose from 4 sizes of the window, rather than resize the box any way you like. However, it's still a great game and you should still play it.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												VVVVVV is the most fun I've had with any game in a long timeThis is an indie 2D platformer.Controls are simple, with just left, right, and a gravity-flip button replacing your jump.Music is amazing, with retro 8/16bit-esque songs so good, some of them made their way to Rock Band as DLC.Graphics are bacic, but charming and colorful, getting the job done.Level design is brillian, throwing unique twists into each section of the game.Exploration is fun with a map that fills in as you go to an area, with the flip feature making travel fast and easyTeleporters are activated as you go, for instant transport if you prefer.Collectable trinkets reward exploration, but never seem impossible to find.Playtime is short at 3-5 hours the first time, but easy to pick up and spend a day re-beating.Difficulty is hard, but other than a few optional collectables, never aggrivating.Bacicly, it's Super Meat Boy but shorter, more retro, and with 80% less rage.And its only 5$.Most fun game ever

Posted: October 19, 2011
												This game is simply fantastic.  The only functions are moving left-to-right and reversing your personal gravity to make it through the game's gauntlet of challenging puzzle rooms, and the likable characters and mind-blowing music are delicious, delicious icing on top of the addictive gameplay.  I've never seen a truer example of genius in simplicity - you owe it to yourself to try this game if you've even a passing interest in platformers.

Posted: August 17, 2011
												With a witty homepage URL (thelettervsixtim.es) and a low price of £4, VVVVVV bought my love with its retro charm and rewarding difficulty.Designed to resemble a Commodore 64 game, VVVVVV launches into a whimsically barebones plot about scientists scattered across "Dimension VVVVVV" when their teleporter malfunctions. The goal of rescuing the crew and escaping the dimension is quickly forgotten in the prescence of finely-tuned pixel-perfect platforming and a contender for "Best Modern Chiptune Soundtrack".The controls are simply 'Left', 'Right', and 'Flip Gravity', but this idea is explored in far more ways than you would expect, with the game constantly training you to understand new concepts without letting up on the difficulty. Checkpoints come just as frequently as death does.Secrets, Challenges and a Level Editor all add significant replay value, and the soundtrack {LINK REMOVED}(bit.ly/hEVe23) will probably haunt your MP3 player for a long time. Definitely worth your time and money.

Posted: August 24, 2011
												When I got this game, I was expecting a short, sidescrolling minigame with 8-bit music. Instead I got a very long, expansive full game with awesome 8-bit music. There is an actual storyline, and a good one at that, and the concept overall of not being able to jump, but rather flipping gravity upside down, works much better than one would think. The game revolves around fast-paced puzzles that you sometimes have to be able to solve at the slightest glance. And even if you know exactly how to solve a puzzle, the smallest miscaluclation in timing will send you flying into a wall of spikes. What I'm saying here is, it's extremely hard. But even so, this isn't the type of game that you can just get frustrated with and turn off. As your death count rises, you feel like you have to keep trying and trying until you get it.And even after you complete the game, there's the level editor that you can use to make your own custom stories and levels, and share them with friends. Overall a great game

Posted: May 25, 2013
												VVVVVV is a retro styled 2D platformer by Terry Cavanagh, creator of dozens of free games. You play as the fearless leader of a team of dimension exploring scientists who inadvertently crash, and are separated. The game involves exploring the strange world you've found yourself in, and reuniting your friends.VVVVVV explores one simple game mechanic: you cannot jump - instead, you reverse your own gravity at the press of a button. The game focuses on playing with this mechanic in a variety of interesting ways.The game is designed not to artificially gate your progress. In VVVVVV there are no locks, no power-ups, no switches, nothing to stop you progressing except the challenges themselves.

Posted: November 28, 2010
												More like "FFFFFF", because that's the sound you're going to be making. A lot. The graphics and music are charming and simplistic, but don't let that fool you. VVVVVV easily ranks as one of the hardest games ever made. There's only three things keeping you from imminent impalement: the left arrow key, the right arrow key, and the invert gravity button. There's no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here: if you can't pass a certain room it's because you're not good enough. No puzzles, no keys, no boss fights and no weapons- just pure skill.

Posted: December 15, 2015
												Fantastically well-done indie game deserving of your attention. One of the most enjoyable compact experiences I have ever had with video games. VVVVVV was one of those games that I picked up and beat in one sitting, and considering how little time I have in my life now due to work, that is an amazing statement.The music is great, it has a story that works with the gimmicks that are presented, and the game is challenging, but not obnoxiously so.It often comes in bundles, and I've seen it dip to nearly nothing during sales. If you're itching to play a 2D sidescroller, I implore you to consider this one. You'll have a great time.Also, for the record, although I didn't go for 100%, I did the hardest challenge in the game, and it makes up the bulk of my playtime on this one. It's called "Veni Vidi Vici,"check it out on Youtube if you're curious, and completing it was one of the most ridiculously satisfying things I've ever done in 20+ years of gaming. It should offer casual gamers a relatively pleasant challenge, and the game poses some optional, harder, sometimes ungodly difficult gameplay as well, for seasoned players.

Posted: December 19, 2011
												If you want to sell folk on VVVVVV, you'll be staring up a hill with a near-right grade that's pestering you to climb it. For one, try to initially wedge mention of it into polite conversation; it's unpronouncable. Should you manage to settle on a verbal interpretation of the title eventually ("vee vee vee vee vee vee", "the letter 'V' six times", "vvvvhhh"), then you've got to sell anyone left remaining on the threadbare graphics and a difficulty that escalates like Wonka's Glass Elevator.It looks like VVVVVV is daring you to love it in the face of stark circumstances. You'll end up liking it, though; the music, speedy gravity-swapping play and psychedically basic visuals create an impressionable space-warping saga of authentic - and repeated - sacrifice. Captain Viridian is one of gaming's truest badasses, which goes a fair jog toward invoking the cliche of being deceived by appearances (much like the rest of this game does.)I did mention the music, right?

Posted: July 27, 2011
												I got VVVVVV with Humble Bundle 3. I had played the free version on Kongregate, and of the bundle's five games, this is the one I wanted to play most. It certainly did not disappoint.This game is a puzzle platformer with only three movement buttons: left, right, and reverse gravity. It does a very good job of exploring what can be done with just that. This game is, above all else, elegant. It's extremely elegant. The controls are simple, but you'll be doing all sorts of crazy tricks by the end.I beat the game in roughly two hours, but that's not saying the game is easy. It's short if completing the story is your goal. In those two hours, I died over 700 times. There are checkpoints between each challenge, so when you die, you can simply try again right away. Some challenges are very hard, especially if you play the extra modes. This game is as hard as you want it to be.I can easily recommend this one for $5. If you're not sure, try the flash version on Kongregate.

												One of the best games I've played.VVVVVV features a very challenging map, amazing soundtrack, and great story, with plenty of minor details mixed in.The soundtrack is one of the best features of this game, in parts where I would've gotten extremely angry due to the amount of deaths I've had trying to navigate it, the soundtrack kept me going. Posted: January 5, 2014
												VVVVVV is one of my favorite precision platformers to date. If you liked Super Meat Boy, They Bleed Pixels, or other challenging games, then VVVVVV is highly recommended. Although not the hardest or longest of games in the same genre, it stands out for its simplistic controls and the use of its gravity manipulation mechanic. VVVVVV has an excellent art style, which clearly pays tribute to the Commodore 64 era and has a fantastic soundtrack to match. Forced to point out its flaws, I would say that it is short (only 3-4 hours long) and comparatively easy, but for the price and for the quality of the game, I would say it is worth the buy.

Posted: June 18, 2014
												This indie game is at the forefront of its genre, with its catchy music and interesting gameplay. The story is pretty good- you have to rescue your lost crewmates after a system meltdown on your ship. The best feature of this game would have to be the creative way of moving around. Along with walking left and right, you can also flip gravity to move onto the ceiling, opening up brand new level designs. The music in this game is something to be praised. Keeping up with its source material's title, the soundtrack is called "PPPPPP" since all of the tracks start with the letter, you guessed it, "P." Overall, I'd say this game is well worth its small price.VVVVVV: Intuituve indie platformer, with great aspects       9/10
